{{Refimprove|date=May 2017}} '''Bomboniere''' (Italian bomboniera, from the french bonbonnière,http://www.larousse.fr/dictionnaires/francais/bonbonni%C3%A8re/10119 a box containing "bonbons" (candies)) also known as "favors", are gifts given by hosts to their guests on special occasions such as [[weddings]], [[baptism]], [[First Communion]] or [[Confirmation]]. They usually include [[Jordan Almonds]], known in Italian as [[Confectionary|Confetti]]. Five sugared almonds symbolize [[health]], [[wealth]], [[happiness]], [[fertility]] and [[Longevity|long life]]. Confetti can be made in many forms using several different ingredients. Sugared almonds are put inside a bag made of tulle or satin and tied with ribbons in assorted colors. The colour of sugared almonds is white for a wedding, [[First Communion]] or [[Confirmation]]; pink or light-blue for birthday or Baptism of a baby girl or baby boy, respectively, red for a graduation, and silver or gold for 25 or 50 year anniversaries. Often they are adorned with dried natural flowers or artificial flowers made of silk or paper. The bag is often given stored inside a small vessel made of silver, crystal or porcelain. In [[Australia]] the word "bomboniere" is applied to any small gift or keepsake given by the hosts to guests at any function held to celebrate weddings, first holy communions and the like. Such gifts may take the form of a wine bottle stopper, glass vase or picture frame as well as the more traditional sugared almonds in decorative bags.{{cite web |url=http://www.petitcadeau.com.au/bomboniere-handcrafted-gifts/about_us |title=About Bomboniere |last= |first= |work=Bomboniere |publisher= |accessdate=2015-11-26 |quote=bomboniere for your wedding, engagement, christening, baptism, holy communion, bridal shower, baby shower, kitchen tea, birthday party, anniversary or any other special occasion }} Image:Samples of Italian favors for First Communion.jpg|Sample of Italian favors used for First Holy Communion Image:portaconfetti.jpg|Sample of Italian favor made with special ribbon containing 5 sugared almonds. Note the printed tags Image:dried_flowers.jpg|Sample of Italian favors made with dried flowers '''Torta Bomboniera'''
A different and new type of bomboniera is the Favor Cake or "Torta Bomboniera" as it is called in Italy. They are made using little carton box forming one or more tier of a "cake".
Inside each box there are the sugared almonds and a card printed with the data of ceremony (names, date etc.). On each box there are glued several types of fine objects made of many materials. Some samples are below, for various ceremonies: Image:TORTA167.jpg|Favor Cake with 40 carton boxes and porcelain flowers, usable for wedding etc. Image:TORTA145.jpg|Favor Cake with 40 carton boxes and Tweety figurines, usable for Birthday, Baptism, First Holy Communion etc. Image:TORTA107.JPG|Favor Cake with 40 carton boxes and glass shells hand-made in Murano (Venice, Italy) Image:TORTA093.jpg|Favor Cake for wedding, with 40 carton boxes and figurines of bride & groom Image:TORTA055.JPG|Favor Cake with 40 carton boxes with [[Minnie Mouse]] and [[Daisy Duck]] figurines, for birthday or Christening Image:TORTA069-24.jpg|Favor Cake with 24 carton boxes and glass sailor ships Image:TORTA185.jpg|Favor Cake with 40 red carton boxes and figurines of graduated Image:TORTA094M.JPG|Favor Cake with 40 carton boxes and glass earth globes '''Evolution of "Torta Bomboniera" to "Pasticceria Artigianale in Porcellana" (Porcelain Artisan Pastries)'''
The following type of Italian Favor Cake is an evolution of above types.
It is made using porcelain boxes shaped and hand decorated like very real edible "bignè" or cream puff.
Inside each box there are five sugared almonds and a card printed with data of ceremony.
For this reasons, the name that Italians give to this new idea is "Pasticceria Artigianale in Porcellana", that is '''Porcelain Artisan Pastries''' Image:TORTA003-A-01.JPG|Favor Cake with porcelain boxes and sugared almonds, heart shaped Image:CAR-G2336.jpg|Porcelain boxes with sugared almonds, round shaped Image:TORTA004-01c.jpg|Favor Cake made with carton boxes and porcelain magnets formed like cream puff and central porcelain box. Inside carton boxes there are the sugared almonds. ==References==
[[Category:Anthropology]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2016}} {{distinguish|text=the journal of the same name published by the University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras Campus, [[Caribbean Studies (UPR)]]}} {{Infobox journal | title = Caribbean Studies
(Études Caribéennes) | cover = | discipline = | abbreviation = Caribb. Stud. | editor = | publisher = [[University of the French West Indies]] (French: ''Université des Antilles'') | country = | frequency = | history = 2003–present | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://journals.openedition.org/etudescaribeennes/?lang=en | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | ISSN = 1779-0980 | eISSN = | OCLC = 958693483 | LCCN = }} '''''Caribbean Studies''''' (''Études caribéennes'', {{ISSN|1779-0980}}) is a [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] established in 2003 by Pascal Saffache. It covers research on problems of the island and tropical worlds (tourism, ecotourism, resource management, natural risks, migrations, identity). The [[editor-in-chief]] is Olivier Dehoorne. Articles are published in French, English, or Spanish. ==See also== * {{C|Caribbean studies|Caribbean studies topics}} * [[Digital Library of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Caribbean studies]] [[Category:Area studies journals]] [[Category:Works about the Caribbean]] {{-}} ---- {{area-journal-stub}} {{Caribbean-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:ChristianSchweigaardStang.jpg|thumb|Christian Schweigaard Stang.]] '''Christian Schweigaard Stang''' (15 March 1900 – 2 July 1977) was a [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] linguist, [[Slavic studies|Slavicist]] and [[Baltic studies|Balticist]], [[professor]] in [[Balto-Slavic languages]] at the [[University of Oslo]] from 1938 until shortly before his death. He specialized in the study of [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] and was highly regarded in [[Lithuania]].<ref name=nbl>{{Cite encyclopedia|last=Hovdhaugen|first=Even|title=Christian Schweigaard Stang|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|year=2004|volume=9|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Christian_Schweigaard_Stang/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=10 April 2009}}</ref>
==Early life== He was born in [[Oslo|Kristiania]] as a son of politician and academic [[Fredrik Stang]] (1867–1941) and his wife Caroline Schweigaard (1871–1900). He was a grandson of [[Emil Stang]] and [[Christian Homann Schweigaard]], and a nephew of [[Emil Stang, Jr.|Emil Stang, Jr]]. He grew up in Kristiania and took his [[examen artium]] 1918 at [[Frogner School]].
==Career== He received his [[Magister (degree)|magister degree]] in comparative [[Indo-European linguistics]] in 1927, and his Ph.D. in 1929. Subsequently he was the University Fellow in comparative Indo-European linguistics for the period 1928-33. From 1938 to 1970 he was professor of Slavonic languages at the University of Oslo. He served as the [[Dean (academic)|dean]] of the Faculty of Humanities from 1958 to 1960.<ref name=nbl/>
Stang was recognized as the leading international expert on Slavic Language learning, on the Baltic-Slavonic comparative linguistics, as well as Lithuanian during his period of study. One of Stang's most noted works was "Vergleichende Grammatik der baltischen Sprachen" (in English "Comparative Grammar of the Baltic languages") published in 1966. In addition to his monumental comparative grammar from 1966, his work on the Baltic and Slavonic verb convincingly demonstrated the close historical connections and interrelationships among the Baltic, Slavonic languages and Germanic languages. In his work on Slavonic accents from 1952, he noted that the Slav and Baltic accent system originally had been identical and that the differences are due to later, secondary changes.<ref name=nbl/> His research on Balto-Slavic comparative accentology culminated with work ''Slavonic Accentuation'' (Oslo, 1957) which, according to [[Frederik Kortlandt|Kortlandt]], "...marked an era in the study of the subject. The importance of this book can hardly be overestimated."<ref>{{harvcoltxt|Kortlandt|1975|p=IX}}</ref> Stang proved in this work that # [[de Saussure's law]] did not operate in Slavic # the [[neoacute]] is due to a retraction of the ictus from a stressed ''[[yer|jer]]'' or from a non-initial vowel with falling intonation # the neo-circumflex was not the result of a [[Common Slavic]] development Furthermore, he demonstrated that # the [[Balto-Slavic acute|acute]] is restricted to paradigms with fixed stress # the neoacute is characteristic of paradigms where the next syllable is stressed in other forms # the [[Balto-Slavic circumflex|circumflex]] occurs on the first syllable of paradigms with final stress in other forms In this way Stang replaced the classical doctrine, which derived the stress pattern of a paradigm from the intonations of the root vowel and the ending, by a doctrine which derives the intonation of the root vowel, when accented, from the stress pattern of the paradigm.
Stang also published several important contributions to comparative Indo-European linguistics.<ref name=nbl/> His contributions include [[Stang's law]], a [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] [[Proto-Indo-European phonology|phonological]] [[Phonological rule|rule]] which was named after him.<ref>{{cite book | title=Indo-European Language and Culture: An Introduction | author=Benjamin W. Fortson | publisher=Blackwell Publishing | year=2004 | isbn=1-4051-0316-7 | page=64 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title= Studies in West Slavic and Baltic linguistics| author= A. A. Barentsen and R. Sprenger | publisher= Rodopi | year=1991 | isbn=978-90-5183-246-4 | page=366 }}</ref>
==Recognition== He was a member of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] from 1932, as well as the [[Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters]] and the [[Royal Swedish Society of Sciences]] in [[Uppsala]]. He was praeces and vice praeces (the position alternates) of the former organization between 1964 and 1971. He was decorated as a Knight, First Class of the [[Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav]] in 1970. He died in July 1977 in [[Kirkenes]].<ref name=nbl/>
==Bibliography== * ''Die westrussische Kanzleisprache des Grossfürstentums Litauen.'' I kommisjon hos [[Jacob Dybwad]], Oslo, 1935 * ''Die altrussische Urkundensprache der Stadt Polozk.'' J. Dybwad, Oslo, 1939 * ''Das slavische und baltische Verbum.'' I kommisjon hos J. Dybwad, Oslo, 1942 * ''Slavonic accentuation.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo 1957 * ''La langue du livre "Uchenie i khitrost ratnago stroeniia piekhotnykh liudei", 1647: une monographie linguistique.'' I kommisjon hos J. Dybwad, Oslo, 1952 * ''Forelesninger over russisk språkhistorie.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo, 1969 * ''Opuscula linguistica. Ausgewählte Aufsätze und Abhandlungen.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo, 1970 * ''Lexikalische Sonderübereinstimmungen zwischen dem Slavischen, Baltischen und Germanischen.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo, 1972 * ''Vergleichende Grammatik der baltischen Sprachen.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo, 1966, 1975 * ''Ergänzungsband: Register, Addenda und Corrigenda zur vergleichenden Grammatik der baltischen Sprachen.'' Universitetsforlaget, Oslo, 1975 * ''Litauish kliáutis - Altnordisch hljóta''
;In collaboration with other authors: * Stang, Christian S, [[Erik Krag|Krag, Erik]], [[Arne Gallis|Gallis, Arne]]: ''Festskrift til professor Olaf Broch på hans 80-årsdag fra venner og elever.'' I kommisjon hos J. Dybwad, Oslo, 1947. * Stang, Christian S og [[Olaf Broch|Broch, Olaf]]: ''Russiske aktstykker fra det 17de århundrede til Finnmarks og Kolahalvøens historie.'' Oslo 1961. * Stang, Christian S og Ruke-Dravina, Velta: ''Donum Balticum. To professor Christian S. Stang on the occasion of his seventieth birthday, 15 March 1970.'' Almqvist & Wiksell, Stockholm, 1970.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * {{Cite journal |first=Frederik |last=Kortlandt |authorlink=Frederik Kortlandt |title=Slavonic Accentuation: A Study in Relative Chronology |year=1975 |publisher=The Peter de Ridder Press |location=Lisse, Netherlands |url=http://www.kortlandt.nl/publications/sa/ |ref=harv}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stang, Christian Schweigaard}} [[Category:Balticists]] [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oslo]] [[Category:Linguists from Norway]] [[Category:Slavists]] [[Category:University of Oslo alumni]] [[Category:University of Oslo faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] [[Category:Stang family (Halden lineage)]]

page.title: Chronological summary of the 2018 Winter Olympics

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2018 Winter Olympics}} This is a chronological summary of the major events of the [[2018 Winter Olympics]] in [[Pyeongchang County]], [[South Korea]]. Two events, the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|curling mixed doubles tournament]] and the [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual|men's normal hill ski jumping competition]], held their preliminary rounds on 8 February. The [[2018 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] took place one day later on 9 February. The last day of competition and the [[2018 Winter Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] was on 25 February.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/schedule | title=PyeongChang 2018 Schedule | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
The games featured 102 events in 15 sports, making it the first Winter Olympics to surpass 100 medal events. Four new disciplines in existing sports were introduced to the Winter Olympic programme in Pyeongchang, including [[Snowboarding#Big air|big air]] snowboarding, [[mixed curling#Mixed doubles|mixed doubles curling]], [[mass start]] [[speed skating]], and mixed team [[alpine skiing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/winter-sports/33056128|title=Winter Olympics: Big air, mixed curling among new 2018 events|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=8 June 2015}}</ref>
A [[Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Unified Korea]] women's ice hockey team competed under a separate IOC country code designation (COR); in all other sports, there was a separate [[North Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics|North Korea team]] and a separate [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics|South Korea team]].<ref>{{cite news|title=N. Korea to send 22 athletes in three sports to PyeongChang Winter Olympics: IOC|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/01/20/0200000000AEN20180120003653315.html|accessdate=20 January 2018|agency=Yonhap|quote=The team [Unified Korea women's ice hockey team] will use the acronym COR and will be the first joint Korean sports team at an Olympic Games.|date=18 January 2018}}</ref> As a result of the suspension of the [[Russian Olympic Committee]] due to the [[Russian doping controversy]], Russian athletes competed as "[[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Olympic Athletes from Russia]]" (OAR) under a neutral flag and with the Olympic anthem playing in any ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|title=IOC suspends Russian NOC and creates a path for clean individual athletes to compete in Pyeongchang 2018 under the Olympic flag|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/ioc-suspends-russian-noc-and-creates-a-path-for-clean-individual-athletes-to-compete-in-pyeongchang-2018-under-the-olympic-flag|publisher=[[IOC]]|accessdate=5 December 2017|date=5 December 2017}}</ref>
:''All dates and times are [[Korea Standard Time|KST]] ([[UTC+09:00|UTC+9]])''
==Calendar== {{2018 Winter Olympics Calendar}}
==Medal table== {{Main|2018 Winter Olympics medal table}} {{:2018 Winter Olympics medal table}}
==Day (−1) — Thursday 8 February== ;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * This was the first day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]].
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The qualification round of the [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual|men's normal hill individual]] was held, with [[Andreas Wellinger]] of Germany taking the top spot with a total score of 133.5.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wellinger leads qualifying for ski jumping normal hill final|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/wellinger-leads-qualifying-for-ski-jumping-normal-hill-final/2018/02/08/65362a9a-0ce0-11e8-998c-96deb18cca19_story.html|work=Associated Press|publisher=Washington Post|first=Jim|last=Armstrong|date=8 February 2018|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref> By participating, Japan's [[Noriaki Kasai]] became the first athlete in history to participate in eight different Winter Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japan's Noriaki Kasai, 45, becomes first athlete to compete in eight Winter Olympics|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/winter-olympics-2018/2018/02/08/japans-noriaki-kasai-45-becomes-first-athlete-compete-eight-winter-olympics/319165002/|newspaper=USA Today|first=Josh|last=Peter|date=8 February 2018|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref>
==Day 0 — Friday 9 February== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * This was the second day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The men's short and the pairs short in the [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Team event|team event]] were held, with the day finishing with [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Canada]] in the lead with 17 points.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2018/02/09/olympics/winter-olympics/olympics-figure-skating/shoma-uno-delivers-stellar-performance-give-japan-early-lead-figure-skating-team-event/#.Wn2IOainGUk|title=Japan sits in third place midway through opening round of team competition|publisher=Japan Times|date=9 February 2018|accessdate=9 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The qualifying rounds of both the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's moguls|men's moguls]] and the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's moguls|women's moguls]] took place, with Canada's [[Mikaël Kingsbury]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2018-fski-mo-m-q/canadas-kingsbury-tops-moguls-qualifying-idUSKBN1FT0HP|title=Canada's Kingsbury tops moguls qualifying|work=Reuters|date=9 February 2018|accessdate=9 February 2018}}</ref> and France's [[Perrine Laffont]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/perrine-laffont-qualifies-first-womens-moguls-usas-morgan-schild-third | title=Perrine Laffont qualifies first in women's moguls | website=NBCOlympics.com |date=8 February 2018|accessdate=9 February 2018}}</ref> taking the top spots, respectively. {{div col end}}
;[[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2018 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|Opening ceremony]] * The opening ceremony at [[Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium]] began at 20:00 KST. [[Yuna Kim]], figure skater gold medalist in [[Figure skating at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|2010]] and silver medalist in [[Figure skating at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|2014]], lit the [[Olympic cauldron]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2018/02/09/winter-olympics-2018-opening-ceremony-review-pyeongchang-unites/|title=Winter Olympics 2018 opening ceremony review: Pyeongchang unites the world in a blizzard of emotion and effects|publisher=The Telegraph|date=9 February 2018}}</ref>
== Day 1 — Saturday 10 February == ===Detailed results (day 1)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|women's sprint]], Germany's [[Laura Dahlmeier]] recorded a time of 21:06.2 with no penalties to win the gold, Norway's [[Marte Olsbu]] had 21:30.4 to win the silver, and [[Veronika Vítková]] of the Czech Republic finished in 21:32.0 to win the bronze.<ref name="Biathlon_Women_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73B_BTHW7.5KMSP-----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Women sprint final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 15 kilometre skiathlon|women's skiathlon]], Sweden's [[Charlotte Kalla]] won the gold with a time of 40:44.9, [[Marit Bjørgen]] of Norway was 7.8 seconds back to win the silver, and [[Krista Pärmäkoski]] of Finland won the bronze at 10.1 back.<ref name="Cross-country_Women_skiathlon">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73B_CCSWSKIATHLN----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's skiathlon final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * This was the third day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]].
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * This was the first day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The first two runs in the [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] were held, with Germany's [[Felix Loch]] leading at the end of the day with a total time of 1:35.299.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73B1_LUGMSINGLES-----------FNL-000200--.pdf | title=Luge: Men's Singles run 2 results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * South Korea's [[Lim Hyo-jun]] set an Olympic record time of 2:10.485 in the final race of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|men's 1500m]] to win the gold. [[Sjinkie Knegt]] of the Netherlands had a time of 2:10.555 to win the silver, and [[Semion Elistratov]] of Russia had a time of 2:10.687 to win the bronze.<ref name="Short_track_Men_1500">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKM1500M-------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short Track Speed Skating: Men's 1,500m final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> * In the qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500m]], [[Elise Christie]] of Great Britain set an Olympic record time of 42.872, only to be beaten in a later heat by South Korea's [[Choi Min-jeong]] by 0.002 seconds.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/elise-christie-into-500m-shorttrack-quarterfinals-after-winning-heat-at-winter-olympics-2018-a3763301.html|title=Elise Christie into 500m short-track quarter-finals after winning heat at Winter Olympics 2018|first=Mark|last=Staniforth|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|publisher=Evening Standard Ltd|date=10 February 2018|accessdate=10 February 2018|quote=The 27-year-old made light of a tough-looking qualification round, leading from start to finish to beat China's Chunyu Qu in an Olympic record time of 42.872 - although her mark lasted precisely eight minutes before it was broken by South Korea's Minjeong Chong.}}</ref> * In the qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay|women's 3000m relay]] were held, the [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|South Korean]] team set an Olympic record time of 4:06.387, which was then beaten by [[China at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|China]] with a time of 4:05.315.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73B_STKW3000MRY4----------HEAT--------.pdf | title=Short Track Speed Skating: Women's 3000 metre relay heats results| website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * In the final of the [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's normal hill individual|men's normal hill individual]], [[Andreas Wellinger]] of Germany won the gold finishing with a total score of 259.1. [[Johann André Forfang]] of Norway finished second with 250.9 points and [[Robert Johansson (ski jumper)|Robert Johansson]] finished third with 249.7 points.<ref name="Ski_jumping_men_normal_hill">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SJP/OWG2018_SJP_C73C3_SJPMNH----------------FNL-0002SJ--.pdf | title=Ski Jumping: Men's Normal Hill Individual final results| website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]] were held, with Norway's [[Marcus Kleveland]] and Canada's [[Maxence Parrot]] winning the two heats with times of 83.71 and 87.36, respectively.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73S_SBDMSS----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's slopestyle qualification results| website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The Netherlands had a [[podium sweep]], winning all three medals in the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metres|women's 3000m]]: [[Carlijn Achtereekte]] finished first with a time of 3:59.21, [[Ireen Wüst]] was second at 0.08 back, and [[Antoinette de Jong]] was third at 0.81 back.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_3000">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKW3000M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's 3000m final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}
===Summary table (day 1)=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Sport ! rowspan="2" | Event ! colspan="3" | Gold medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Silver medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Bronze medalist(s) ! rowspan="2" | {{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} |- | [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] | [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|Women's sprint]] | [[Laura Dahlmeier]] | {{flagIOC|GER|2018 Winter}} | | [[Marte Olsbu]] | {{flagIOC|NOR|2018 Winter}} | [[Veronika Vítková]] | {{flagIOC|CZE|2018 Winter}} | <ref name="Biathlon_Women_sprint"/> |- | [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] | [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 15 kilometre skiathlon|Women's skiathlon]] | [[Charlotte Kalla]] | {{flagIOC|SWE|2018 Winter}} | | [[Marit Bjørgen]] | {{flagIOC|NOR|2018 Winter}} | [[Krista Pärmäkoski]] | {{flagIOC|FIN|2018 Winter}} | <ref name="Cross-country_Women_skiathlon"/> |- | [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] | [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|Men's 1500 m]] | [[Lim Hyo-jun]] | == Day 2 — Sunday 11 February == ===Detailed results (day 2)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|men's downhill]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was postponed until Thursday 15 February due to high winds.<ref name="men's downhill postponed">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/winter-olympics/43020921 |title=Winter Olympics: Men's downhill postponed because of high winds |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=11 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="Alpine skiing reschedule1"/>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * In the [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint|men's sprint]], Germany's [[Arnd Peiffer]] recorded a time of 23:38.8 with no penalties to win the gold, [[Michal Krčmář]] of the Czech Republic had 23:43.2 to win the silver, and [[Dominik Windisch]] of Italy finished at 23:46.5 to win the bronze.<ref name="Biathlon_Men_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73B_BTHM10KMSP------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Men sprint final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * In the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 30 kilometre skiathlon|men's skiathlon]], Norway completed a [[podium sweep]], with [[Simen Hegstad Krüger]] (1:16:20.0), [[Martin Johnsrud Sundby]] (1:16:28.0) and [[Hans Christer Holund]] (1:16:29.9) winning the gold, silver and bronze respectively.<ref name="Cross-country_Men_skiathlon">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73B_CCSMSKIATHLN----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's skiathlon final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]]: ** The fourth and final day of the round robin stage. ** Tie-breaker match: {{flagIOC|CHN|2018 Winter}} 7–9 '''{{flagIOC|NOR|2018 Winter}}'''
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The ice dancing short, the ladies' short, and the pairs free program in the [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Team event|team event]] were held. The day finished with [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Canada]] leading with 45 points. Russian [[Evgenia Medvedeva]] set a new [[ISU Judging System#Best scores|best score]] of 81.06 in the ladies' short program.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://wintergames.ap.org/article/k-pop-fan-medvedeva-finds-her-groove-set-record | title=K-pop fan Medvedeva finds her groove to set record | work=Associated Press | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In final medal round of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's moguls|women's moguls]], France's [[Perrine Laffont]] won the gold with a score of 78.65, Canada's [[Justine Dufour-Lapointe]] won the silver with a score of 78.56, and [[Yuliya Galysheva]] of Kazakhstan won the bronze with a score of 77.40.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Women_moguls">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73M_FRSWMO----------------FNL-000300--.pdf | title=Freestyle Skiing: Women's moguls final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * This was the second day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * In the [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]], Austria's [[David Gleirscher]] had a total time of 3:10.702 to win the gold, [[Chris Mazdzer]] of the United States was 0.026 back to finish in second, and Germany's [[Johannes Ludwig]] was 0.230 back to win the bronze.<ref name="Luge_men_singles">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73B2_LUGMSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Luge: Men's Singles final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]], [[Redmond Gerard]] of the United States won the gold (87.16), Canada's [[Maxence Parrot]] won the silver (86.00), and Canada's [[Mark McMorris]] won the bronze (85.20).<ref name="Snowboarding_men_slopestyle">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73S_SBDMSS----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's slopestyle final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]] was cancelled due to high winds. All competitors will compete in a two-run final round instead of the typical two-run qualification round and three-run final round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/womens-snowboard-slopestyle-qualifying-cancelled | title=Women's snowboard slopestyle qualifying cancelled | website=NBCOlympics.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * In the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|men's 5000m]], [[Sven Kramer]] of the Netherlands set an Olympic record time of 6:09.76 to win the gold. Canada's [[Ted-Jan Bloemen]] finished at 6:11.616 to win the silver and Norway's [[Sverre Lunde Pedersen]] finished at 6:11.618 to win the bronze.<ref name="Speed_skating_men_5000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKM5000M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed Skating: Men's 5000m final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 3 — Monday 12 February == ===Detailed results (day 3)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's giant slalom|women's giant slalom]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was postponed until Thursday 15 February due to high winds.<ref name="wommen's giant slalom postponed">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/winter-olympics/43027402 |title=Winter Olympics: Giant slalom postponed as high winds continue |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=12 February 2018 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's pursuit|men's pursuit]] was won by [[Martin Fourcade]] of France in a time of 32:51.7 with one penalty round, while silver went to [[Sebastian Samuelsson]] of Sweden with a time of 33:03.7 and one penalty round, and bronze went to [[Benedikt Doll]] of Germany with a time of 33:06.8 and one penalty round.<ref name="Biathlon_Men_pursuit">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73D_BTHM12.5KMPU----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Men's 12.5km pursuit cumulative results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's pursuit|women's pursuit]] was won by [[Laura Dahlmeier]] of Germany, the winner of the [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|sprint event]], in a time of 30:35.3 with one penalty round, while silver went to [[Anastasiya Kuzmina]] of Slovakia with a time of 31:04.7 and four penalty rounds, and bronze went to [[Anaïs Bescond]] of France with a time of 31:04.9 and one penalty round.<ref name="Biathlon_Women_pursuit">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73D_BTHW10KMPU------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Women's 10km pursuit cumulative results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]] semi-finals: ** '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2018 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|NOR|2018 Winter}} ** '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2018 Winter}}''' 7–5 {{flagIOC|OAR|2018 Winter}}
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The final day of the [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Team event|team event]] was held, featuring the men's free program, the ladies' free program, and the ice dancing free program. [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Canada]] won the gold with 73 points, the [[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|Olympic Athletes from Russia]] won the silver with 66 points, and the [[United States at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Figure skating|United States]] won the bronze with 62 points.<ref name="Figure_skating_team">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/en/figure-skating/cumulative-result-team-event.htm | title=Figure skating: Team event cumulative results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The final rounds of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's moguls|men's moguls]]. [[Mikaël Kingsbury]] of Canada scored 86.63 to win the gold, [[Matt Graham (skier)|Matt Graham]] of Australia won the silver with a score of 82.57, and Japan's [[Daichi Hara]] won the bronze with a 82.19 score.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Men_moguls">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73M_FRSMMO----------------FNL-000300--.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's moguls final 3 results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The third day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The first two runs in the [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] were held, with Germany's [[Natalie Geisenberger]] leading at the end of the day with a total time of 1:32.454.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73B1_LUGWSINGLES-----------FNL-000200--.pdf | title=Luge: Women's Singles run 2 results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's normal hill individual|women's normal hill individual]] was won by Norway's [[Maren Lundby]] with 264.6 points, while silver went to [[Katharina Althaus]] of Germany with 252.6 points, and bronze went to Japan's [[Sara Takanashi]] with 243.8 points.<ref name="Ski_jumping_Women_normal_hill_individual">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SJP/OWG2018_SJP_C73C3_SJPWNH----------------FNL-0002SJ--.pdf | title=Ski jumping: Women's normal hill individual results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * Under the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]] two-run final round that was held due to the high winds on the previous day, [[Jamie Anderson (snowboarder)|Jamie Anderson]] of the United States recorded a score of 83.00 to win the gold, [[Laurie Blouin]] of Canada won the silver with a 76.33 score, and Finland's [[Enni Rukajärvi]] had a 75.38 to finish with the bronze.<ref name="Snowboarding_Women_slopestyle">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73S_SBDWSS----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's slopestyle final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]] was held, with [[Chloe Kim]] (United States) recording the best score of 95.50.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73H_SBDWHP----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's halfpipe qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|women's 1500 m]] was won by [[Ireen Wüst]] of the Netherlands in a time of 1:54.35. Silver went to Japan's [[Miho Takagi (speed skater)|Miho Takagi]] in a time of 1:54.55, while bronze went to [[Marrit Leenstra (speed skater)|Marrit Leenstra]] of the Netherlands in a time of 1:55.26.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_1500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKW1500M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's 1,500m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 4 — Tuesday 13 February == ===Detailed results (day 4)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's combined|men's combined]] was won by Austria's [[Marcel Hirscher]] in a time of 2:06.52. Silver and bronze went to [[Alexis Pinturault]] and [[Victor Muffat-Jeandet]] of France with times of 2:06.75 and 2:07.54, respectively.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Men_combined">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C92A_ALPMAC----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Men's combined results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint|men's individual sprint]] was won by Norway's [[Johannes Høsflot Klæbo]] in a time of 3:05.75, followed by Italy's [[Federico Pellegrino]] with a time of 3:07.09 and [[Aleksandr Bolshunov]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a time of 3:07.11.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Men_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73D3_CCSMSPRINT------------------------.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's sprint results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's sprint|women's individual sprint]] was won by Sweden's [[Stina Nilsson]] in a time of 3:03.84, followed by Norway's [[Maiken Caspersen Falla]] with a time of 3:06.87 and [[Yulia Belorukova]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a time of 3:07.21.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Women_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73D3_CCSWSPRINT------------------------.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's sprint results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]]: ** Bronze medal game: '''{{flagIOC|OAR|2018 Winter}}''' 8–4 {{flagIOC|NOR|2018 Winter}} *** The Russian team would later be stripped of their bronze medals on 22 February, after [[Aleksandr Krushelnitskiy]] failed a doping test. The medals were then awarded to the Norwegian team instead.<ref name="Curling_mixed_medals_stripped"/> ** Gold medal game: '''{{flagIOC|CAN|2018 Winter}}''' 10–3 {{flagIOC|SUI|2018 Winter}}
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The fourth day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The final runs in the [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] were won by Germany's [[Natalie Geisenberger]] in a time of 3:05.232, ahead of fellow German [[Dajana Eitberger]] with a time of 3:05.599 and [[Alex Gough (luger)|Alex Gough]] of Canada with a time of 3:05.644.<ref name="Luge_Women_singles">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73B2_LUGWSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Luge: Women's singles final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * The final heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500 m]] were won by [[Arianna Fontana]] of Italy in a time of 42.569. Silver went to [[Yara van Kerkhof]] of the Netherlands with a time of 43.256, while bronze went to Canada's [[Kim Boutin]] with a time of 43.881.<ref name="Short_track_speed_skating_Women_500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKW500M--------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Women's 500m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 m]] were held. Canada's [[Charles Hamelin]] set a new Olympic record time of 1:23.407.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKM1000M-------------HEAT--------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Men's 1,000m heats results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|men's 5000 m relay]] took place. The [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics|South Korean]] team qualified for the final in the fastest time, setting an Olympic record of 6:34.510.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73B_STKM5000MRY4----------HEAT--------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Men's 5,000m relay heats results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The finals of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]] were won by [[Chloe Kim]] of the United States with a score of 98.25. Silver went to China's [[Liu Jiayu]] with a score of 89.75, while bronze went to [[Arielle Gold]] of the United States with a score of 85.75.<ref name="Snowboarding_Women_halfpipe">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73H_SBDWHP----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's halfpipe results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]].
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|men's 1500 m]] was won by [[Kjeld Nuis]] of the Netherlands in a time of 1:44.01, followed by his compatriot [[Patrick Roest]] with a time of 1:44.86 and South Korea's [[Kim Min-seok (speed skater)|Kim Min-seok]] with a time of 1:44.93.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_1500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKM1500M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's 1,500m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=13 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 5 — Wednesday 14 February == ===Detailed results (day 5)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's slalom|women's slalom]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was postponed to Friday 16 February due to high winds.<ref name="Women_slalom_postponed">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/notices/urgent-reannouncement-today-s-event-schedule-changed-yongpyong-alpine-centre-alpine-skiing-ladies-slalom-date-rescheduled-to-16-feb | title=Today's event schedule changed – Yongpyong Alpine Centre, Alpine Skiing Ladies' Slalom date rescheduled to 16 Feb | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's individual|women's individual]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was postponed to Thursday 15 February due to high winds.<ref name="Women_individual_biathlon_postponed">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/notices/urgent-announcement-schedule-changes-alpensia-biathlon-centre-on-14-15-feb | title=Schedule changes – Alpensia Biathlon Centre on 14–15 Feb | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The first day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The first day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Pairs skating|pairs skating]] short program took place, with the Chinese pair of [[Wenjing Sui]] and [[Cong Han]] leading at this stage with a score of 82.89.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C77A_FSKXPAIRS-------------QUAL000100--.pdf | title=Figure skating: Pairs skating short program results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The first day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The fourth day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Doubles|doubles]] were won by [[Tobias Wendl]] and [[Tobias Arlt]] of Germany in a time of 1:31.697, followed by [[Peter Penz]] and [[Georg Fischler]] of Austria with a time of 1:31.785, and [[Toni Eggert]] and [[Sascha Benecken]] of Germany with a time of 1:31.987.<ref name="Luge_Doubles">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73B2_LUGODOUBLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Luge: Doubles final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * The [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Individual normal hill/10 km|individual normal hill/10 km]] was won by Germany's [[Eric Frenzel]] in a time of 24:51.4, ahead of Japan's [[Akito Watabe]] with a time of 24:56.2 and Austria's [[Lukas Klapfer]] with a time of 25:09.5.<ref name="Nordic_combined_Men_individual_normal_hill_10km">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/NCB/OWG2018_NCB_C73B4_NCBMNH10KM------------FNL-0001CC--.pdf | title=Nordic combined: Men's individual normal hill/10km results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The finals of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]] was won by [[Shaun White]] of the United States with a score of 97.75. Silver went to Japan's [[Ayumu Hirano]] with a score of 95.25, while bronze went to Australia's [[Scott James]] with a score of 92.00.<ref name="Snowboarding_Men_halfpipe">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73H_SBDMHP----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's halfpipe results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 m]] was won by [[Jorien ter Mors]] of the Netherlands in an Olympic record time of 1:13.56. Silver went to Japan's [[Nao Kodaira]] with a time of 1:13.82, while bronze went to her compatriot [[Miho Takagi (speed skater)|Miho Takagi]] with a time of 1:13.98.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_1000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKW1000M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's 1,000m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 6 — Thursday 15 February == ===Detailed results (day 6)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * Because of high winds on Sunday 11 February, the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|men's downhill]] was moved to this day.<ref name="Alpine skiing reschedule1">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/10/sports/olympics-downhill-postponed.html |title=An Olympic Ski Race Is Blown 4 Days Off Course, but Onto a TV-Friendly Path |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> The race was won by Norway's [[Aksel Lund Svindal]] in a time of 1:40.25, followed by his compatriot [[Kjetil Jansrud]] with a time of 1:40.37, and [[Beat Feuz]] of Switzerland with a time of 1:40.43.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Men_downhill">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73A_ALPMDH----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Men's downhill official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's super-G|men's super-G]], originally scheduled on this day, was postponed to Friday 16 February to make room for the men's downhill competition.<ref name="Alpine skiing reschedule1"/> * Because of high winds on Monday 12 February, the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's giant slalom|women's giant slalom]] was moved to this day.<ref name="wommen's giant slalom postponed"/> The race was won by [[Mikaela Shiffrin]] of the United States in a time of 2:20.02, followed by Norway's [[Ragnhild Mowinckel]] with a time of 2:20.41, and Italy's [[Federica Brignone]] with a time of 2:20.48.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Women_giant_slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73C_ALPWGS----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Women's giant slalom official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's individual|men's individual]] was won by [[Johannes Thingnes Bø]] of Norway in a time of 48:03.8 with two penalties, followed by Slovenia's [[Jakov Fak]] with a time of 48:09.3 and no penalties, and Austria's [[Dominik Landertinger]] with a time of 48:18.0 and no penalties.<ref name="Biathlon_Men_individual">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73A_BTHM20KMIS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Men's 20km individual final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's individual|women's individual]] was moved to this day due to high winds on the original day (Wednesday 14 February).<ref name="Women_individual_biathlon_postponed"/> Gold went to [[Hanna Öberg]] of Sweden with a time of 41:07.2 and no penalties. Silver went to Slovakia's [[Anastasiya Kuzmina]] with a time of 41:31.9 and two penalties, while bronze went to Germany's [[Laura Dahlmeier]] with a time of 41:48.4 and one penalty.<ref name="Biathlon_Women_individual">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73A_BTHW15KMIS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Women's 15km individual final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 10 kilometre freestyle|women's 10 km freestyle]] was won by [[Ragnhild Haga]] of Norway in a time of 25:00.5. Silver went to Sweden's [[Charlotte Kalla]] with a time of 25:20.8, while bronze was shared by Norway's [[Marit Bjørgen]] and Finland's [[Krista Pärmäkoski]] with an identical time of 25:32.4.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Women_10km_freestyle">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73A_CCSW10KMIS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's 10km freestyle results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The second day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The second day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Pairs skating|pairs skating]] free program was won by [[Aljona Savchenko]] and [[Bruno Massot]] of Germany with a score of 235.90. Silver went to [[Sui Wenjing]] and [[Han Cong]] of China with a score of 235.47, while bronze went to [[Meagan Duhamel]] and [[Eric Radford]] of Canada with a score of 230.15.<ref name="Figure_skating_Pairs_skating">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C73B_FSKXPAIRS-------------------------.pdf | title=Figure skating: Pairs skating results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The qualifying rounds of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's aerials|women's aerials]] took place. The best qualifying score came from [[Alla Tsuper]] of Belarus, with a score of 99.37.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73A_FRSWAE----------------QUAL000200--.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's aerials qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The second day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The fifth day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Luge pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Luge]] * The [[Luge at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Team relay|team relay]] was won by the [[Germany at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Luge|German]] team in a time of 2:24.517, followed by the [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Luge|Canadian]] team with a time of 2:24.872 and the [[Austria at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Luge|Austrian]] team with a time of 2:24.988.<ref name="Luge_Team_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/LUG/OWG2018_LUG_C73C2_LUGXRELAY4------------------------.pdf | title=Luge: Team relay final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * The first two runs of the [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's|men's skeleton]] took place, with [[Sungbin Yun]] (South Korea) leading at this stage with a total time of 1:40.35.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SKN/OWG2018_SKN_C73B1_SKNMSINGLES-----------FNL-000200--.pdf | title=Skeleton: Men's run 2 results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's snowboard cross|men's snowboard cross]] final was won by [[Pierre Vaultier]] of France, ahead of Australia's [[Jarryd Hughes]] and Spain's [[Regino Hernández]].<ref name="Snowboarding_Men_snowboard_cross">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73X2_SBDMSBX---------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's snowboard cross results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 10,000 metres|men's 10,000 m]] was won by [[Ted-Jan Bloemen]] of Canada with an Olympic record time of 12:39.77. Silver went to [[Jorrit Bergsma]] of the Netherlands with a time of 12:41.98, while bronze went to Italy's [[Nicola Tumolero]] with a time of 12:54.32.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_10000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKM10000M------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's 10,000m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 7 — Friday 16 February == ===Detailed results (day 7)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's super-G|men's super-G]] was moved to this day due to the rescheduling of the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's downhill|men's downhill]] competition.<ref name="Alpine skiing reschedule1"/> It was won by [[Matthias Mayer]] of Austria in a time of 1:24.44. Silver went to Switzerland's [[Beat Feuz]] with a time of 1:24.57, while bronze went to Norway's [[Kjetil Jansrud]] with a time of 1:24.62.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Men_super_G">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73A_ALPMSG----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Men's super-G official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's slalom|women's slalom]] was moved to this day due to high winds on the original day (Wednesday 14 February).<ref name="Women_slalom_postponed"/> It was won by [[Frida Hansdotter]] of Sweden in a time of 1:38.63, ahead of Switzerland's [[Wendy Holdener]] with a time of 1:38.68 and Austria's [[Katharina Gallhuber]] with a time of 1:38.95.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Women_slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73C_ALPWSL----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Women's slalom official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 15 kilometre freestyle|men's 15 km freestyle]] was won by [[Dario Cologna]] of Switzerland in a time of 33:43.9, followed by Norway's [[Simen Hegstad Krüger]] with a time of 34:02.2 and [[Denis Spitsov]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a time of 34:06.9.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Men_15km_freestyle">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73A_CCSM15KMIS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's 15km freestyle results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The third day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The third day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] short program.
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The finals of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's aerials|women's aerials]] were won by [[Hanna Huskova]] of Belarus with a score of 96.14. Silver went to China's [[Zhang Xin (skier)|Zhang Xin]] with a score of 95.52, while bronze went to her compatriot [[Kong Fanyu]] with a score of 70.14.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Women_aerials">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73A_FRSWAE----------------FNL-000300--.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's aerials results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The third day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]].
;[[File:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * The final two runs of the [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's|men's skeleton]]. The event was won by [[Yun Sung-bin]] of South Korea in a time of 3:20.55, followed by [[Nikita Tregubov]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a time of 3:22.18 and [[Dominic Parsons]] of Great Britain with a time of 3:22.20.<ref name="Skeleton_Men">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SKN/OWG2018_SKN_C73B2_SKNMSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Skeleton: Men's official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> * The first two runs of the [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's|women's skeleton]].
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The qualification round of the [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill individual|men's large hill individual]].
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's snowboard cross|women's snowboard cross]] was won by [[Michela Moioli]] of Italy. Silver went to France's [[Julia Pereira de Sousa Mabileau]], while bronze went to [[Eva Samková]] of the Czech Republic.<ref name="Snowboarding_Women_snowboard_cross">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73X2_SBDWSBX---------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's snowboard cross results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 5000 metres|women's 5000 m]] was won by [[Esmee Visser]] of the Netherlands in a time of 6:50.23, ahead of [[Martina Sáblíková]] of the Czech Republic with a time of 6:51.85 and [[Natalya Voronina]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a time of 6:53.98.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_5000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKW5000M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf |title=Speed skating: Women's 5,000m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}
