== Day 8 — Saturday 17 February == ===Detailed results (day 8)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's super-G|women's super-G]] was won by [[Ester Ledecká]] of the Czech Republic in a time of 1:21.11, ahead of Austria's [[Anna Veith]] with a time of 1:21.12 and Liechtenstein's [[Tina Weirather]] with a time of 1:21.22.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Women_super_G">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73A_ALPWSG----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Women's super-G official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's mass start|women's mass start]] was won by [[Anastasiya Kuzmina]] of Slovakia with a time of 35:23.0. [[Darya Domracheva]] of Belarus was 18.8 back to win silver and [[Tiril Eckhoff]] of Norway was 27.7 back to win the bronze.<ref name="Biathlon_Women_mass_start">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73E_BTHW12.5KMMS----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Women's mass start results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 4 × 5 kilometre relay|women's 4 × 5 km relay]] was won by the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Norwegian]] team in a time of 51:24.3, ahead of [[Sweden at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Sweden]] with a time of 51:26.3 and the [[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Olympic Athletes from Russia]] with a time of 52:07.6.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Women_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73C_CCSW4X5KM-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's 4 × 5km relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The fourth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The fourth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] free program. The competition was won by [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] of Japan with a score of 317.85. Silver went to his compatriot [[Shoma Uno]] with a score of 306.90, while bronze went to Spain's [[Javier Fernández (figure skater)|Javier Fernández]] with a score of 305.24.<ref name="Figure_skating_Men_singles">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C73B_FSKMSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Figure skating: Men's singles results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's slopestyle|women's slopestyle]] was won by [[Sarah Höfflin]] of Switzerland with a score of 91.20. Sliver went to her compatriot [[Mathilde Gremaud]] with a score of 88.00, while bronze went to Great Britain's [[Isabel Atkin]] with a score of 84.60.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Women_slopestyle">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73S_FRSWSS----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's slopestyle results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying rounds of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's aerials|men's aerials]] took place, with the Olympic Athlete from Russia [[Ilya Burov|Ilia Burov]] recording the best qualifying score of 126.55.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73A_FRSMAE----------------QUAL000200--.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's aerials qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] quarter-finals: ** '''{{flagdeco|IOC}} [[Russia women's national ice hockey team|Olympic Athletes from Russia]]''' 6–2 {{ihw|SUI}} ** '''{{ihw|FIN}}''' 7–2 {{ihw|SWE}} * The fourth day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]].
;[[File:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * Canada's [[Samuel Girard]] won the final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 m]] with a time of 1:24.650 to the gold. [[John-Henry Krueger]] of the United States finished second with 1:24.864, and South Korea's [[Seo Yi-ra]] finished third at 1:31.619.<ref name="Short track_Men_1000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKM1000M-------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short Track Speed Skating: Men's 1,000m final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> * The final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|women's 1500 m]] was won by South Korea's [[Choi Min-jeong]] with a time of 2:24.948. China's [[Li Jinyu]] finished second at 2:25.703 and Canada's [[Kim Boutin]] finished third at 2:25.834.<ref name="Short track_Women_1500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKW1500M-------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short Track Speed Skating: Women's 1,500m final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Skeleton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Skeleton]] * [[Lizzy Yarnold]] of Great Britain won the gold in the [[Skeleton at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's|women's skeleton]] with a total time of 3:27.28. Germany's [[Jacqueline Lölling]] was second with a total time of 3:27.73, and Great Britain's [[Laura Deas]] was third with 3:27.90.<ref name="Women_skeleton">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SKN/OWG2018_SKN_C73B2_SKNWSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Women's skeleton results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The final round of the [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill individual|men's large hill individual]] was won by [[Kamil Stoch]] of Poland with a total score of 285.7. Germany's [[Andreas Wellinger]] won the silver with a score of 282.3 and [[Robert Johansson (ski jumper)|Robert Johansson]] of Norway had a total of 275.3 to win the bronze.<ref name="Ski_jumping_Men_large_hill_individual">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SJP/OWG2018_SJP_C73C3_SJPMLH----------------FNL-0002SJ--.pdf | title=Ski jumping: Men's large hill individual results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 9 — Sunday 18 February == ===Detailed results (day 9)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's giant slalom|men's giant slalom]] was won by [[Marcel Hirscher]] of Austria in a time of 2:18.04. Silver went to Norway's [[Henrik Kristoffersen]] with a time of 2:19.31, while bronze went to France's [[Alexis Pinturault]] with a time of 2:19.35.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Men_giant_slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73C_ALPMGS----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Men's giant slalom official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|men's mass start]] was won by [[Martin Fourcade]] of France in a [[photo finish]] ahead of Germany's [[Simon Schempp]], both with a time of 35:47.3. Bronze went to Norway's [[Emil Hegle Svendsen]] with a time of 35:58.5.<ref name="Biathlon_Men_mass_start">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73E_BTHM15KMMS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Men's mass start final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The first two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man]] took place, with Germany's [[Nico Walther]] and [[Christian Poser]] leading at this stage with a total time of 1:38.39.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BOB/OWG2018_BOB_C73B1_BOBMTEAM2-------------FNL-000200--.pdf | title=Bobsleigh: Men's two-man heat 2 results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 4 × 10 kilometre relay|men's 4 × 10 km relay]] was won by the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Norwegian]] team in a time of 1:33:04.9, ahead of the [[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Olympic Athletes from Russia]] with a time of 1:33:14.3 and [[France at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|France]] with a time of 1:33:41.8.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Men_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73C_CCSM4X10KM------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's 4 x 10km relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The fifth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The fifth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's slopestyle|men's slopestyle]] was won by [[Øystein Bråten]] of Norway with a score of 95.00. Silver went to [[Nick Goepper]] of the United States with a score of 93.60. The bronze medal went to [[Alex Beaulieu-Marchand]] of Canada with a score of 92.40.<ref name="Ski_Freestyle_Men_ski_slopestyle">{{cite web|title=Freestyle skiing: Men's slopestyle results|website=pyeongchang2018.com|url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73S_FRSMSS----------------------------.pdf|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> * The finals of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's aerials|men's aerials]] were won by [[Oleksandr Abramenko]] of the Ukraine with a score of 128.51. Silver went to China's [[Jia Zongyang]] with a score of 128.05, while bronze went to [[Ilya Burov]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with a score of 122.17.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Men_aerials">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73A_FRSMAE----------------FNL-000300--.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's aerials results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] 5–8th place semi-finals: ** '''{{ihw|SUI}}''' 2–0 {{ihw|Korea|unification}} ** {{ihw|SWE}} 1–2 '''{{ihw|JPN}}''' * The fifth day of matches in the group stage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]].
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The qualification heats of the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's team pursuit|men's team pursuit]] took place, with the [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics|South Korean]] team recording the best time of 3:38.29.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73E1_SSKMTEAMPU------------QFNL--------.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's team pursuit quarterfinals results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|women's 500 m]] was won by [[Nao Kodaira]] of Japan in an Olympic record time of 36.94. Silver went to South Korea's [[Lee Sang-hwa]] with a time of 37.33, while bronze went to the Czech Republic's [[Karolína Erbanová]] with a time of 37.34.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKW500M--------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's 500m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 10 — Monday 19 February == ===Detailed results (day 10)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The final two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man]]. The gold medal was shared by [[Justin Kripps]] and [[Alexander Kopacz]] of Canada and [[Francesco Friedrich]] and [[Thorsten Margis]] of Germany with an identical time of 3:16.86. Bronze went to [[Oskars Melbārdis]] and [[Jānis Strenga]] of Latvia with a time of 3:16.91.<ref name="Bobsleigh_Two_man">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BOB/OWG2018_BOB_C73B2_BOBMTEAM2-------------------------.pdf | title=Bobsleigh: Two-man official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The sixth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The sixth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|ice dancing]] short program took place, with the Canadian pair of [[Tessa Virtue]] and [[Scott Moir]] leading at this stage with a score of 83.67.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C77A_FSKXICEDANCE----------QUAL000100--.pdf | title=Figure skating: Ice dancing short program results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The qualifying rounds of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]] took place. Canadian [[Cassie Sharpe]] qualified with the best score of 93.40.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/en/freestyle-skiing/results-ladies-ski-halfpipe-qual-000200-.htm | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's halfpipe qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] semi-finals: ** '''{{ihw|USA}}''' 5–0 {{ihw|FIN}} ** '''{{ihw|CAN}}''' 5–0 {{flagdeco|IOC}} [[Russia women's national ice hockey team|Olympic Athletes from Russia]]
;[[File:Ski jumping pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ski jumping]] * The [[Ski jumping at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's large hill team|men's large hill team]] was won by the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Ski jumping|Norwegian]] team with a score of 1098.5. Silver went to the [[Germany at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Ski jumping|German]] team with a score of 1075.7, while bronze went to the [[Poland at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Ski jumping|Polish]] team with a score of 1072.4.<ref name="Ski_jumping_Men_large_hill_team">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SJP/OWG2018_SJP_C73D3_SJPMLHTEAM4-----------FNL-0002SJ--.pdf | title=Ski jumping: Men's large hill team results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's big air|women's big air]] took place, with Austrian [[Anna Gasser]] qualifying with the best score of 98.00.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73B_SBDWBA----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's big air qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The qualification heats of the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's team pursuit|women's team pursuit]] took place. The [[Netherlands at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Netherlands]] qualified with the fastest time, setting a new Olympic record of 2:55.61.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73E1_SSKWTEAMPU------------QFNL--------.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's team pursuit qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 m]] was won by [[Håvard Holmefjord Lorentzen]] of Norway in an Olympic record time of 34.41, ahead of South Korea's [[Cha Min-kyu]] with a time of 34.42 and China's [[Gao Tingyu]] with a time of 34.65.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_500m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKM500M--------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's 500m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 11 — Tuesday 20 February == ===Detailed results (day 11)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed relay|mixed relay]] was won by the [[France at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|French]] team in a time of 1:08:34.3, ahead of the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Norwegian]] team with a time of 1:08:55.2 and the [[Italy at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Italian]] team with a time of 1:09:01.2.<ref name="Biathlon_Mixed_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73C_BTHXRELAY4------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Mixed relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The first two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]].
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The seventh day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The seventh day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|ice dancing]] free program was held. The competition was won by [[Tessa Virtue]] and [[Scott Moir]] of Canada, who set a world record total score of 206.07. [[Gabriella Papadakis]] and [[Guillaume Cizeron]] of France won silver with 205.28. [[Maia Shibutani]] and [[Alex Shibutani]] of the United States were third with 192.59.<ref name="Figure skating_Ice_dancing">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C73B_FSKXICEDANCE----------------------.pdf | title=Figure skating: Ice dancing official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In the final of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's halfpipe|women's halfpipe]], Canada's [[Cassie Sharpe]] won the gold with a score of 95.80, France's [[Marie Martinod]] scored a 92.60 to win the silver, and [[Brita Sigourney]] of the United States finished third with 91.60.<ref name="Freestyle_skiing_Women_halfpipe">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73H_FRSWHP----------------------------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's halfpipe final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying rounds of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]] were held. [[Aaron Blunck]] (United States) qualified with the best score of 94.40.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73H_FRSMHP----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's halfpipe qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]]: ** Seventh place game: '''{{ihw|SWE}}''' 6–1 {{ihw|Korea|unification}} ** Fifth place game: '''{{ihw|SUI}}''' 1–0 {{ihw|JPN}} * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] qualification playoffs: ** '''{{ih|USA}}''' 5–1 {{ih|SVK}} ** {{ih|SLO}} 1–2 '''{{small|[[Overtime|OT]]}} {{ih|NOR}}''' ** '''{{ih|FIN}}''' 5–2 {{ih|KOR}} ** {{ih|SUI}} 1–2 '''{{small|[[Overtime|OT]]}} {{ih|GER}}'''
;[[File:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * In the [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Individual large hill/10 km|individual large hill/10 km]], Germany achieved a [[podium sweep]], with gold going to [[Johannes Rydzek]] with a time of 23:52.5, silver going to [[Fabian Rießle]] with a time of 23:52.9, and bronze going to [[Eric Frenzel]] with a time of 23:53.3.<ref name="Nordic_combined_Individual_large_hill_10km">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/NCB/OWG2018_NCB_C73B4_NCBMLH10KM------------FNL-0001CC--.pdf | title=Nordic combined: Individual large hill/10km results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * The final heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay|women's 3000 m relay]] were won by the [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|South Korean]] team in a time of 4:07.361, ahead of the [[Italy at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Italian]] team (4:15.901). After the [[China at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Chinese]] and [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Canadian]] teams were disqualified in the A final, the bronze medal was awarded to the [[Netherlands at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Dutch]] team, who finished the B final (originally to determine fifth place) in a world record time of 4:03.471.<ref name="Short_track_speed_skating_Women_3000m_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73B_STKW3000MRY4----------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Women's 3,000m relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 m]] took place. The fastest time in any heat, 1:29.519, was recorded by Dutch skater [[Suzanne Schulting]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKW1000M-------------HEAT--------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Women's 1,000m qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> * The qualifying heats of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 m]] took place. [[Dajing Wu]] (China) set a new Olympic record time of 40.264.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKM500M--------------HEAT--------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Men's 500m qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 12 — Wednesday 21 February == ===Detailed results (day 12)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's downhill|women's downhill]] was won by Italy's [[Sofia Goggia]] in a time of 1:39.22, followed by Norway's [[Ragnhild Mowinckel]] with a time of 1:39.31, and [[Lindsey Vonn]] of the United States with a time of 1:39.69.<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Women_downhill">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73A_ALPWDH----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Women's downhill official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The final two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]] were won by [[Mariama Jamanka]] and [[Lisa Buckwitz]] of Germany in a time of 3:22.45. Silver went to [[Elana Meyers|Elana Meyers Taylor]] and [[Lauren Gibbs]] of the United States with a time of 3:22.52, while bronze went to Canada's [[Kaillie Humphries]] and [[Phylicia George]] with a time of 3:22.89.<ref name="Bobsleigh_Two_woman">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BOB/OWG2018_BOB_C73B2_BOBWTEAM2-------------------------.pdf | title=Bobsleigh: Two-woman official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's team sprint|men's team sprint]] was won by the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Norwegian]] team in a time of 15:56.26, ahead of the team composed of [[Olympic Athletes from Russia at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Olympic Athletes from Russia]] with a time of 15:57.97 and the [[France at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|French]] team with a time of 15:58.28.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Men_team_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73F3_CCSMTEAMSP2-----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's team sprint results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's team sprint|women's team sprint]] was won by the [[United States at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|United States]] team in a time of 15:56.47, ahead of the [[Sweden at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Swedish]] team with a time of 15:56.66 and the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Cross-country skiing|Norwegian]] team with a time of 15:59.44.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Women_team_sprint">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73F3_CCSWTEAMSP2-----------------------.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's team sprint results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The eighth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]. * The eighth day of matches in the round robin stage of the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]].
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|ladies' singles]] short program took place, with [[Alina Zagitova]] (an Olympic Athlete from Russia) recording the best score of 82.92.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C77A_FSKWSINGLES-----------QUAL000100--.pdf | title=Figure skating: Women's singles short program results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's ski cross|men's ski cross]] was won by [[Brady Leman]] of Canada, followed by Switzerland's [[Marc Bischofberger]] and the Olympic Athlete from Russia [[Sergey Ridzik]].<ref name="Freestyle skiing: Men ski cross">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73X2_FRSMSX----------------------------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's ski cross results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] bronze medal game: ** '''{{ihw|FIN}}''' 3–2 {{flagdeco|IOC}} [[Russia women's national ice hockey team|Olympic Athletes from Russia]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] quarter-finals: ** '''{{ih|CZE}}''' 3–2 {{small|'''[[Shootout (ice hockey)|GWS]]'''}} {{ih|USA}} ** '''{{flagdeco|IOC}} [[Russia men's national ice hockey team|Olympic Athletes from Russia]]''' 6–1 {{ih|NOR}} ** '''{{ih|CAN}}''' 1–0 {{ih|FIN}} ** {{ih|SWE}} 3–4 '''{{small|[[Overtime|OT]]}} {{ih|GER}}'''
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's big air|men's big air]] took place. [[Carlos Garcia Knight]] (New Zealand) qualified with the best score of 97.50.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73B_SBDMBA----------------QUAL--------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's big air qualification results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The final heats of the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's team pursuit|men's team pursuit]] was won by the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|Norwegian]] team in a time of 3:37.32, ahead of the [[South Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|South Korean]] team with a time of 3:38.52. Bronze went to the [[Netherlands at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|Netherlands]], who won the bronze race in a time of 3:38.40, ahead of [[New Zealand at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|New Zealand]]'s 3:43.54.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_team_pursuit">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73E3_SSKMTEAMPU------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's team pursuit results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> * The final heats of the [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's team pursuit|women's team pursuit]] was won by the [[Japan at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|Japanese]] team in an Olympic record time of 2:53.89, ahead of the [[Netherlands at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|Dutch]] team with a time of 2:55.48. Bronze went to the [[United States at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|United States]], who won the bronze race in a time of 2:59.27, ahead of [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Speed skating|Canada]]'s 2:59.72.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_team_pursuit">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73E3_SSKWTEAMPU------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's team pursuit results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 13 — Thursday 22 February == ===Detailed results (day 13)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's slalom|men's slalom]] was won by Sweden's [[André Myhrer]] with a total time of 1:38.99. Switzerland's [[Ramon Zenhäusern]] won the silver with a total time of 1:39.33, and Austria's [[Michael Matt]] was third with a total time of 1:39.66.<ref name="Alpine skiing: Men slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73C_ALPMSL----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine Skiing: Men's slalom results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> * Because of expected high winds on Friday 23 February, the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's combined|women's combined]] was moved to this day.<ref name="Women_combined_moved_forward">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/notices/urgent-announcement-schedule-changes-ladies-alpine-combined-jeongseon-on-23-feb-men-s-slalom-yongpyong-on-22-feb | title=Schedule changes: Ladies' Alpine Combined on 23 Feb | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> [[Michelle Gisin]] of Switzerland won the gold with a time of 2:20.90, [[Mikaela Shiffrin]] of the United States won silver with a time of 2:21.87, and [[Wendy Holdener]] of Switzerland was third with 2:22.34.<ref name="Alpine skiing: Women combined">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73E_ALPWAC----------------------------.pdf | title=Alpine Skiing: Women's combined results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's relay|women's relay]] was won by [[Belarus at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Belarus]] with a time of 1:12:03.4. [[Sweden at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Sweden]] finished in second with 1:12:14.1 and [[France at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|France]] was third with 1:12:21.0.<ref name="Biathlon: Women's relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73C_BTHW4X6KM-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Women's relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * It was announced that as a result of Russian curlier [[Alexander Krushelnitskiy]] failing a doping test for [[meldonium]], he and his partner [[Anastasia Bryzgalova]] were stripped of their bronze medals for the [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed doubles tournament|mixed doubles tournament]]. The medals were then awarded to [[Kristin Skaslien]] and [[Magnus Nedregotten]] of Norway, who had lost to the Russian team in the bronze medal game.<ref name="Curling_mixed_medals_stripped">{{cite news|title=Winter Olympics: Russia curler Alexander Krushelnitsky stripped of bronze for doping|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/winter-olympics/43152299|accessdate=22 February 2018|agency=[[BBC]]|date=22 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]]: ** Tie-breaker match: {{flagIOC|GBR|2018 Winter}} 5–9 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2018 Winter}}''' ** Semi-finals: *** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2018 Winter}}''' 9–3 {{flagIOC|SUI|2018 Winter}} *** {{flagIOC|CAN|2018 Winter}} 3–5 '''{{flagIOC|USA|2018 Winter}}'''
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * In the final of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe|men's halfpipe]], [[David Wise (freestyle skier)|David Wise]] of the United States won the gold with a score of 97.20, [[Alex Ferreira]] of the United States was second with 96.40, and [[Nico Porteous]] of New Zealand had a 94.80 to finish with the bronze.<ref name="Freestyle skiing: Men halfpipe">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73H_FRSMHP----------------------------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Men's halfpipe results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] gold medal game: ** {{ihw|CAN}} 2–3 {{small|'''[[Shootout (ice hockey)|GWS]]'''}} '''{{ihw|USA}}'''
;[[File:Nordic combined pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Nordic combined]] * The [[Nordic combined at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Team large hill/4 × 5 km|team large hill/4 × 5 km]] was won by the [[Germany at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Nordic combined|German]] team in a time of 46:09.8, ahead of the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Nordic combined|Norwegian]] team with a time of 47:02.5 and the [[Austria at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Nordic combined|Austrian]] team with a time of 47:17.6.<ref name="Nordic_combined_Team_large_hill_4x5km">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/NCB/OWG2018_NCB_C72C4_NCBMLH4X5KM-----------FNL-0001CC--.pdf | title=Nordic combined: Team large hill/4x5km results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Short track speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Short track speed skating]] * In the final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 m]], [[Suzanne Schulting]] of the Netherlands won gold with a time of 1:29.778, Canada's [[Kim Boutin]] finished at 1:29.956 to win silver, and Italy's [[Arianna Fontana]] finished third at 1:30.656.<ref name="Short track speed skating: Women's 1000 m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKW1000M-------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Women's 1000 m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> * China's [[Wu Dajing]] set a world record in the final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 m]] with a time of 39.584. Korea's [[Hwang Dae-heon]] and [[Lim Hyo-jun]] finished second and third with times of 39.854 and 39.919, respectively.<ref name="Short track speed skating: Men's 500 m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73A_STKM500M--------------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Men's 500 m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> * In the final of the [[Short track speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|men's 5000 m relay]], the [[Hungary at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Hungarian]] team set an Olympic record time of 6:31.971 to win the gold. [[China at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|China]] finished second (6:32.035) and [[Canada at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Short track speed skating|Canada]] finished third (6:32.282).<ref name="Short track speed skating: Men's 5000 m relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/STK/OWG2018_STK_C73B_STKM5000MRY4----------FNL---------.pdf | title=Short track speed skating: Men's 5000 m relay results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's parallel giant slalom|men's parallel giant slalom]] was originally scheduled for this day, but was postponed to Saturday 24 February due to high winds.<ref name="Parallel_giant_slalom_and_women_ski_cross_postponed">{{cite web | url= | title=Schedule changes: Snowboard parallel giant slalom on 22 Feb & Freestyle skiing ladies' ski cross on 23 Feb | website=pyeongchang2018.com }}</ref> * The qualification round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's parallel giant slalom|women's parallel giant slalom]] was originally scheduled for this day, but was postponed to Saturday 24 February due to high winds.<ref name="Parallel_giant_slalom_and_women_ski_cross_postponed"/> * Because of expected high winds on Friday 23 February, the final round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's big air|women's big air]] was moved to this day.<ref name="Women_big_air_moved_forward">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/notices/urgent-announcement-snowboard-big-air-ladies’-finals-scheduled-for-23-feb-changed | title=Snowboard Big Air Ladies’ Finals Scheduled for 23 Feb CHANGED | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> [[Anna Gasser]] of Austria won the gold with a score of 185.00, [[Jamie Anderson (snowboarder)|Jamie Anderson]] of the United States won the silver with 177.25, and [[Zoi Sadowski-Synnott]] of New Zealand was third with 157.50.<ref name="Snowboarding: women big air">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73B_SBDWBA----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's big air results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
{{div col end}}

== Day 14 — Friday 23 February == ===Detailed results (day 14)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * The [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's combined|women's combined]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was moved back to Thursday 22 February due to high winds being expected.<ref name="Women_combined_moved_forward"/>
;[[File:Biathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Biathlon]] * The [[Biathlon at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's relay|men's relay]] was won by the [[Sweden at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Swedish]] team in a time of 1:15:16.5, ahead of the [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|Norwegian]] team with a time of 1:16:12.0 and the [[Germany at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Biathlon|German]] team with a time of 1:17:23.6.<ref name="Biathlon_Men_relay">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BTH/OWG2018_BTH_C73C_BTHM4X7.5KM-----------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Biathlon: Men's relay final results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=23 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] bronze medal game. ** {{flagIOC|CAN|2018 Winter}} 5–7 '''{{flagIOC|SUI|2018 Winter}}''' * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] semi-finals. ** '''{{flagIOC|KOR|2018 Winter}}''' 8–7 {{flagIOC|JPN|2018 Winter}} ** '''{{flagIOC|SWE|2018 Winter}}''' 10–5 {{flagIOC|GBR|2018 Winter}}
;[[File:Figure skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Figure skating]] * The [[Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|ladies' singles]] free program was held. The competition was won by Russian [[Alina Zagitova]] with a total score of 239.57, Russian [[Evgenia Medvedeva]] won silver with 238.26, and Canadian [[Kaetlyn Osmond]] was third with 231.02.<ref name="Figure_skating_Women_singles">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FSK/OWG2018_FSK_C73B_FSKWSINGLES-----------------------.pdf | title=Figure skating: Women's singles results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=23 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Freestyle skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Freestyle skiing]] * The qualification round of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's ski cross|women's ski cross]] was originally scheduled for this day, but was moved back to Thursday 22 February due to high winds.<ref name="Parallel_giant_slalom_and_women_ski_cross_postponed"/> * The [[Freestyle skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's ski cross|women's ski cross]] was won by [[Kelsey Serwa]] of Canada, followed by Canada's [[Brittany Phelan]] and Switzerland's [[Fanny Smith]].<ref name="Freestyle skiing: Women ski cross">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/FRS/OWG2018_FRS_C73X2_FRSWSX----------------------------.pdf | title=Freestyle skiing: Women's ski cross results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=23 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] semi-finals: ** {{ih|CZE}} 0–3 '''{{flagdeco|IOC}} [[Russia men's national ice hockey team|Olympic Athletes from Russia]]''' ** {{ih|CAN}} 3–4 '''{{ih|GER}}'''
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * The final round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's big air|women's big air]] was originally scheduled to take place, but was moved back to Thursday 22 February due to high winds being expected.<ref name="Women_big_air_moved_forward"/>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|men's 1000 m]] was won by [[Kjeld Nuis]] of the Netherlands in a time of 1:07.95. Silver went to Norway's [[Håvard Holmefjord Lorentzen]] with a time of 1:07.99, while bronze went to South Korea's [[Kim Tae-yun (speed skater)|Kim Tae-yun]] with a time of 1:08.22.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_1000m">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73A_SSKM1000M-------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's 1,000m results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=23 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 15 — Saturday 24 February == ===Detailed results (day 15)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Alpine skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Alpine skiing]] * In the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Mixed team|mixed team]], the [[Switzerland at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Alpine skiing|Swiss]] team defeated [[Austria at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Alpine skiing|Austria]], 3–1, in the gold medal final. The bronze medal final between [[Norway at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Alpine skiing|Norway]] and [[France at the 2018 Winter Olympics#Alpine skiing|France]] ended in a 2–2 tie, with Norway being awarded the bronze based on total time (41.17 to 41.29).<ref name="Alpine_skiing_Mixed_team">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/ALP/OWG2018_ALP_C73G_ALPXPLTEAM4-----------FNL---------.pdf | title=Alpine skiing: Mixed team official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The first two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man]].
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * The [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's 50 kilometre classical|men's 50 km classical]] was won by Finland's [[Iivo Niskanen]] in a time of 2:08:22.1, ahead of [[Aleksandr Bolshunov]] and [[Andrey Larkov]] of the Olympic Athletes from Russia with times of 2:08:40.8 and 2:10:59.6, respectively.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Men_50km_classical">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73E_CCSM50KMMS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Men's 50km classical results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Curling pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Curling]] * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] gold medal game. ** {{flagIOC|SWE|2018 Winter}} 7–10 '''{{flagIOC|USA|2018 Winter}}''' * The [[Curling at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] bronze medal game. ** {{flagIOC|GBR|2018 Winter}} 3–5 '''{{flagIOC|JPN|2018 Winter}}'''
;[[File:Ice hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Ice hockey]] * The [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] bronze medal game. ** {{ih|CZE}} 4–6 '''{{ih|CAN}}'''
;[[File:Snowboarding pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Snowboarding]] * In the final round of the [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's big air|men's big air]], Canada's [[Sebastien Toutant]] won gold with a total score of 174.25. [[Kyle Mack]] of the United States was second with 168.75 and Great Britain's [[Billy Morgan (snowboarder)|Billy Morgan]] won bronze with 168.00.<ref name="Snowboarding: Men big air">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73B_SBDMBA----------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's big air results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's parallel giant slalom|men's parallel giant slalom]]: The qualification rounds, originally scheduled for Thursday 22 February, was moved to this day to precede the final rounds of this event.<ref name="Parallel_giant_slalom_and_women_ski_cross_postponed"/> In the gold medal race, [[Nevin Galmarini]] of Switzerland beat [[Lee Sang-ho (snowboarder)|Lee Sang-ho]] of South Korea by 0.43 seconds. In the bronze medal race, Slovenia's [[Žan Košir]] beat France's [[Sylvain Dufour]] by 1.49 seconds.<ref name="Snowboarding: Men parallel giant slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73P3_SBDMPGS---------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Men's parallel giant slalom results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Snowboarding at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's parallel giant slalom|women's parallel giant slalom]]: The qualification round, originally scheduled for Thursday 22 February, was moved to this day to precede the final rounds of this event.<ref name="Parallel_giant_slalom_and_women_ski_cross_postponed"/> [[Ester Ledecká]] of the Czech Republic beat [[Selina Jörg]] of Germany in the gold medal race by 0.46 seconds. In the bronze medal race, Germany's [[Ramona Theresia Hofmeister]] beat Russia's [[Alena Zavarzina]] by 4.07 seconds.<ref name="Snowboarding: Women parallel giant slalom">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SBD/OWG2018_SBD_C73P3_SBDWPGS---------------------------.pdf | title=Snowboarding: Women's parallel giant slalom results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> ** Ledecká, who also won gold in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's super-G|Alpine skiing women's super-G]], became the first woman to win gold in two different sports during the same Winter Olympics.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/winter-olympics/42981486 | title=Winter Olympics: Ester Ledecka wins second gold medal in Pyeongchang | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Speed skating pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating]] * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's mass start|men's mass start]] was won by [[Lee Seung-hoon]] of South Korea with 60 points, ahead of Belgium's [[Bart Swings]] with 40 points and [[Koen Verweij]] of the Netherlands with 20 points.<ref name="Speed_skating_Men_mass_start">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73B_SSKMMS----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Men's mass start results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref> * The [[Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's mass start|women's mass start]] was won by Japan's [[Nana Takagi]] with 60 points, ahead of South Korea's [[Kim Bo-reum]] with 40 points and [[Irene Schouten]] of the Netherlands with 20 points.<ref name="Speed_skating_Women_mass_start">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/SSK/OWG2018_SSK_C73B_SSKWMS----------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Speed skating: Women's mass start results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>

== Day 16 — Sunday 25 February == ===Detailed results (day 16)=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Bobsleigh pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] * The final two runs of the [[Bobsleigh at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man]] were held. The competition was won by the German team of [[Francesco Friedrich]], [[Candy Bauer]], [[Martin Grothkopp]], and [[Thorsten Margis]] with a total time of 3:15.85. The silver was shared by another German team ([[Nico Walther]], [[Kevin Kuske]], [[Alexander Rödiger]], and [[Eric Franke]]) and a South Korean team ([[Won Yun-jong]], [[Jun Jung-lin]], [[Seo Young-woo]], and [[Kim Dong-hyun (bobsledder)|Kim Dong-hyun]]) with identical total time of 3:16.38.<ref name="Bobsleigh_Four_man">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/BOB/OWG2018_BOB_C73B2_BOBOTEAM4-------------------------.pdf | title=Bobsleigh: Four-man official results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>
;[[File:Cross country skiing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Cross-country skiing]] * Norway's [[Marit Bjørgen]] won the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Women's 30 kilometre classical|women's 30 km classical]] with a time of 1:22:17.6. Finland's [[Krista Pärmäkoski]] finished second at 1:24:07.1 and Sweden's [[Stina Nilsson]] finished third at 1:24:16.5.<ref name="Cross_country_skiing_Women_30km_classical">{{cite web | url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/resOWG2018/pdf/OWG2018/CCS/OWG2018_CCS_C73E_CCSW30KMMS------------FNL-000100--.pdf | title=Cross-country skiing: Women's 30km classical results | website=pyeongchang2018.com | accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>

;[[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2018 Winter Olympics closing ceremony|Closing ceremony]] * The closing ceremony took place at [[Pyeongchang Olympic Stadium]] at 20:00 KST. It included the traditional handover to [[Beijing]], the host city of the [[2022 Winter Olympics|next Winter Olympics]] in 2022.
