revision.comment: removed [[Category:Education]]; added [[Category:Education in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
In U.S. education, '''deeper learning''' is a set of student educational outcomes including acquisition of robust core academic content, higher-order thinking skills, and learning dispositions. Deeper learning is based on the premise that the nature of work, civic, and everyday life is changing and therefore increasingly requires that formal education provides young people with mastery of skills like [[analytic reasoning]], complex [[problem solving]], and [[teamwork]]. Deeper learning is associated with a growing movement in [[Education in the United States|U.S. education]] that places special emphasis on the ability to apply knowledge to real-world circumstances and to solve novel problems.{{cite book|last1=Martinez|first1=Monica|last2=McGrath|first2=Dennis|title=Deeper Learning: How Eight Innovative Public Schools Are Transforming Education in the Twenty-First Century|date=2014|publisher=The New Press|location=New York|isbn=978-1-59558-959-0|pages=1–21|url=http://thenewpress.com/books/deeper-learning}} "Deeper learning" was first introduced by the [[William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]] in 2010{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} and specified a set of educational outcomes-{{cite web|title=Deeper Learning Defined|url=http://www.hewlett.org/uploads/documents/Deeper_Learning_Defined__April_2013.pdf|website=Hewlett Foundation|publisher=Hewlett Foundation|accessdate=April 2013}} * Mastery of rigorous academic content * Development of critical thinking and problem-solving skills * The ability to work collaboratively * Effective oral and written communication * Learning how to learn * Developing and maintaining an academic mindset{{cite web|url=http://www.mindsetworks.com/go/academic-mindsets/ |title= academic mindset |publisher=Mindset Works |accessdate=28 September 2014}} A number of U.S. schools and school districts serving a broad socio-economic spectrum apply deeper learning as an integral component of their instructional approach.{{cite journal|last1=Mehta|first1=Jal|last2=Fine|first2=Sarah|title=The Elusive Quest for Deeper Learning|journal=Harvard Education Letter|date=July–August 2014|volume=30|issue=4|url=http://hepg.org/hel-home/issues/30_4/helarticle/the-elusive-quest-for-deeper-learning}} ==History== While the term "deeper learning" is relatively new, the notion of enabling students to develop skills that empower them to apply learning and to adapt to and thrive in [[post-secondary education]] as well as [[career]] and life is not. A number of significant antecedents to deeper learning exist. For example, American [[philosopher]], [[psychologist]] and [[education reform|educational reformer]] [[John Dewey]] (1859–1952) made a strong case for the importance of education not only as a place to gain content knowledge, but also as a place to learn how to live. Like modern proponents of deeper learning, Dewey believed that students thrive in an environment where they are allowed to experience and interact with the [[curriculum]], and all students should have the opportunity to take part in their own learning. Dewey's arguments undergirded the movements of [[progressive education]] and [[Constructivism (philosophy of education)|constructivist education]], which called for teaching and learning beyond [[Rote learning|rote content knowledge]]. In the 1990s, skills-based education saw a resurgence with the advent of the "[[21st century skills|21st Century Skills]]" movements and the "Partnership for 21st Century skills".{{cite web |url=http://www.p21.org/about-us/our-history |title=About us |publisher=Partnership for 21st Century |accessdate=28 September 2014}} In 2012 the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] of the [[National Academies]] issued ''Education for Life and Work: Developing Transferrable Knowledge and Skill in the 21st Century,'' a report on deeper learning re-elevating the issue and summarizing research evidence on its outcomes to date.{{cite book|last1=Pellegrino|first1=James W.|last2=Hilton|first2=Margaret L.|title=Education for Life and Work: Developing Transferrable Knowledge and Skill in the 21st Century|date=2012|publisher=The National Academies Press|location=Washington, D.C.|url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=13398}} These were followed by a multi-collection series of major voices (e.g. Ken Kay, Linda Darling Hammond, Yong Zhao, James Pellegrino and others) in the Leading Edge publications ''Rethinking Student Learning'' and ''Deeper Learning: Beyond 21st Century Skills''. In addition, Solution Tree published ''How to Teach Thinking in the Common Core'' and ''Enriched Learning Projects'' by James Bellanca. Teacher College Press also published "how to" books to help teachers with deeper learning instruction. Included in these are Reuven Feuerstein's ''Beyond Smarter'' and James Bellanca's ''Focus Factor'' and ''Classrooms without Borders''. ==Skills and competencies== According to labor economists Frank Levy of [[MIT]] and Richard Murnane of [[Harvard University|Harvard’s Graduate School of Education]], since 1970, with the economic changes brought about by technology and [[globalization]], employers’ demands for workers with routine, repetitive skills—whether manual or cognitive—have dropped steeply, while demand for those with deeper learning competencies like complex thinking and communications skills has soared.{{cite book|last1=Murnane|first1=Richard J.|last2=Levy|first2=Frank|title=Teaching the New Basic Skills: Principles for Educating Children to Thrive in a Changing Economy|date=1996|publisher=Free Press|location=New York}} Levy and Murnane argue that the success of the U.S. economy will rely on the nation’s ability to give students the "foundational skills in problem-solving and communications that computers don’t have."{{cite book|last1=Levy|first1=Frank|last2=Murnane|first2=Richard|title=Dancing with Robots: Human Skills for Computerized Work|publisher=Third Way|url=http://content.thirdway.org/publications/714/Dancing-With-Robots.pdf}} Research by Cassel and Kolstad found that by the year 2000 the top skills demanded by U.S. [[Fortune 500]] companies had shifted from traditional reading, writing and arithmetic to teamwork, problem solving, and interpersonal skills.{{cite journal|last1=Cassel|first1=R.N.|last2=Kolstad|first2=R.|title=The critical job-skills requirements for the 21st century: Living and working with people|journal=Journal of Instructional Psychology|date=1998|volume=25|issue=3|pages=176–180}} A 2006 [[Conference Board]] survey of some 400 employers revealed that key deeper learning competencies were the most important for new entrants into the workforce. Essential capabilities included oral and written communications and critical thinking/problem solving. The [[Conference Board]] findings indicate that "applied skills on all educational levels trump basic knowledge and skills, such as Reading Comprehension and Mathematics ... while the ‘three Rs’ are still fundamental to any new workforce entrant’s ability to do the job, employers emphasize that applied skills like Teamwork/Collaboration and Critical Thinking are ‘very important’ to success at work."{{cite book|title=Are They Ready to Work? Employers' Perspectives on the Basic Knowledge and Applied Skills of New Entrants to the 21st Century U.S. Workforce|date=2006|publisher=Partnership for 21st Century Skills|location=Washington, D.C.|url=http://www.p21.org/storage/documents/FINAL_REPORT_PDF09-29-06.pdf}} In 2002 a coalition of national business community, education leaders, and policymakers founded the Partnership for 21st Century Skills (now the Partnership for 21st Century Learning, or P21), a [[non-profit]] organization. P21's goal is to foster a national conversation on "the importance of 21st century skills for all students" and "position 21st century readiness at the center of US K-12 education". The organization has released reports exploring how to integrate the Four Cs approach into learning environments.[http://www.p21.org/about-us/our-history P21 Our History]. Retrieved 2016-03-05 Their research and publications included an identification of deeper learning competencies and skills they called the [[Four Cs of 21st century learning]] (collaboration, communication, critical thinking, creativity). In a 2012 survey conducted by the [[American Management Association]] (AMA), executives found a need for highly skilled employees to keep up with the fast pace of change in business and to compete on a global level. The survey identified three of the "Four Cs" ([[critical thinking]], communication and collaboration) as the top three skills necessary for these employees.{{cite book|title=Critical Skills Survey|date=2012|publisher=American Management Association|location=New York|url=http://playbook.amanet.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/2012-Critical-Skills-Survey-pdf.pdf}} ==Instructional reforms== Deeper learning practitioners have developed a number instructional reform methods and built a variety of classroom, school, and district models. While stressing robust content mastery, instructors ask students to "move beyond basic comprehension and algorithmic procedures and engage in skills that lie at the top of traditional learning taxonomies—analysis, synthesis, and creation," according to Harvard education scholars Jal Mehta and Sarah Fine.{{cite journal|last1=Mehta|first1=Jal|last2=Fine|first2=Sarah|title=Teaching differently ... Learning deeply|journal=Kappan Magazine|date=2012|volume=94|issue=2|pages=31–35|url=http://www.myboe.org/cognoti/content/file/resources/documents/82/82c7708a/82c7708a4655db2ef23ed0529db9c5bd057e5cae/HighTechHighMehtaandFinePDK20121.pdf}} "Students are treated as active meaning makers with the capacity to do interesting and valuable work now ... the purpose of school is not so much to prepare students for a hypothetical future as to support them in engaging with the complex challenges that professional work at its best entails."
In its 2012 report ''Education for Life and Work'', the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] identified the following research-based methods for developing deeper learning: * Use multiple and varied representations of concepts and tasks * Encourage elaboration, questioning, and self-explanation * Engage learners in challenging tasks, with supportive guidance and feedback * Teach with examples and cases * Prime student motivation * Use formative assessment Deeper examination of what "best practices" evidence shows connect teaching methods to the development of the Partnership for 21st Century Learning's 4C frameworkhttp://www.p21.org/framework and the competencies identified in the Hewlett model for deeper learning,http://www.hewlett.org/education/deeper learning give a sharper picture of "what works" in terms of instructional strategies and tools. For instance, the Marzano Lab has identified the high effects of cooperative learning to develop collaboration, graphic organizers to advance critical thinking, feedback to sharpen communication, advance organizers to enrich entry activities in PBLs, etc.http://www.marzanoresearch.com/instructional strategies John Hattie's meta-analysis of visible learning is even more specific. Strategies that promote metacognition, reflection, student feedback, creativity, inquiry and more support the type of teaching that most enriches mindful, deeper learning. In addition, his studies detail how surface teaching strategies such as lectures, worksheets, overly frequent testing and others do little for achievement or deeper learning.http://www.treasury/gov.nz/publications//hattie For young learners, the Center for Childhood Creativity has identified the powerful role of creative thinking in the classroom.http://centerforchildhoodcreativity.org While evidence supporting the direct impact of education organized around deeper learning outcomes in driving academic achievement is not robust to date, it continues to build. P21 is leading an effort at the University of Connecticut to remedy this. As early as 2008 a study of seven hundred California students demonstrated that students exposed to math instruction designed to develop deeper learning competencies significantly outperformed peers taught through more traditional methods. ==Network of schools== A number of educational reform school networks across the country focus on developing deeper learning competencies.{{cite journal|last1=Rothman|first1=Robert|title=Diving into Deeper Learning: Schools gear up to promote thinking skills|journal=Harvard Education Letter|date=March–April 2013|volume=29|issue=2|url=http://hepg.org/hel-home/issues/29_2/helarticle/diving-into-deeper-learning}} While committed to deeper learning educational outcomes, these networks, however, vary in their instructional models and approaches to school design. They include: [[Asia Society|Asia Society International Studies Schools Network]], Big Picture Learning,{{cite web |url=http://www.bigpicture.org/about-us/ |title=About us |publisher= Big Picture Learning |accessdate=28 September 2014}} ConnectEd California,{{cite web |url=http://www.connectedcalifornia.org/about |title= About us |publisher= ConnectEd California |accessdate=28 September 2014}} [[EdVisions Schools]], [[Envision Schools|Envision Education]], Expeditionary Learning,{{cite web |url=http://elschools.org/about-us |title= About us |publisher= Expeditionary Learning |accessdate=28 September 2014}} High Tech High, Internationals Network for Public Schools, New Tech Network, New Visions for Public Schools. A 2014 trade book by educational consultant Monica Martinez highlights features of Deeper Learning schools. Because of limits imposed by state and federal laws, public school districts face the largest challenges to bring deeper learning back into their schools. The Partnership for 21st Century Learning (http://www.p21.org/exemplars initiated the identification of exemplar schools which were relying on inclusion of 21st Century Skills as a base component for bringing deeper learning experiences to all children. Some of these exemplar schools come from the reform networks, but many are schools and districts that targeted deeper learning instruction and outcomes as their mission but without the benefits in money, public relations and compliance given to charter schools. To further advance the notion, P21 created a Blogazine to "connect the dots between 21st Century skills and deeper learning outcomes".http://www.p21.org/our-work/p21blog The blog articles are written pro bono by major educational writers who advocate for the paradigm shift to Deeper Learning as well as by a balance of school leaders, teachers, professional learning specialists and others who are incorporating deeper learning practices into their curricula, instruction, assessment and system change plans. In its second year, the no-fee online P21 Blogazine expanded into a three times weekly online journal as a major voice of deeper learning theory and practice. Its aim was to seed understanding of the principles and picture the best practices occurring in innovative schools and classrooms. It expanded its distribution by partnering with major 21st Century learning organizations such as Connected Educator's Month, chapters of ASCD, school districts and many P21 sponsors.It introduced a self-directed professional learning option for educators who are interested in reading, discussing and putting action plans garnered from P21 posts into classrooms. As more schools, especially public schools, began to plan to integrate deeper learning, a group of Illinois advocates, aligned with P21, searched for assistance to scale best 21st Century teaching practices into classrooms. Already successful exemplars in the US and abroad were relying on versions of project based learning (problem-based, inquiry-based, product-making, project- based); there was great variation in effectiveness. After reviewing models from multiple sources, the Illinois Consortium for 21st Century Schools determined none were adequate for systemic integration into schools or systems. The consortium team, made up of volunteer, long experienced professional developers, classroom teachers, administrators and school change specialists, all with experience in ''public'' school reform, adapted and redesigned the most effective PBL models and designed a new school-wide approach of PBL that included explicit instruction and assessment of the 4CS as advocated by the Partnership, technology, reflection and a 5th C, cultural responsiveness. These elements were integrated into a PBL design cycle, called MindQuest21. Creative making was balanced with critical thinking to allow for teachers to challenge the narrow framework of the standards which ignored the creative C.http://www.ilc21.org/MindQuest21 The resulting cost-effective, grass roots model intentionally targeted deeper learning outcomes with carefully selected deeper learning methods. It was piloted in an urban school with a large English Language Learning population, a suburban affluent district with four schools and a suburban, but economically and racially changing district, all using limited but existing funds. At the same time that site administrators and teachers participated in a year-long, twice monthly interaction with the ''MindQuest21'' team, that same team interacted with district administrators to change systemwide practices to those ways of leading that would readily support the new focus on deeper learning practices and outcomes. What emerged was a scalable and sustainable model for changing the school and district systems so that the systems, including teacher evaluation, would support new approaches to teaching and learning in ''every'' classroom and a multi-faceted system of evaluation would show significant deeper learning (including standardized test content) gains for students, their schools and the district. It would also show to any visitor that a different way of teaching and learning existed as the norm in every classroom, engaging students every moment of the day in deeper learning processes aimed at explicit deeper learning outcomes.http://www.ilc21.org/ The MindQuest21 approach was not an isolated example. As the P21 Exemplar identification program showed, more and more schools, often acting alone, sometimes in concert with other schools in a district, were shifting the learning paradigm from surface learning pushed by NCLB recall tests to deeper learning stimulated by entrepreneurial administrators and teachers. In a like manner, creative teachers who were able to defy the punishment threats of NCLB, did the same.http://www.p21.org/blogazine ==Assessment== The majority of tests used in the current U.S. school system focus mainly on achievement of content knowledge and rely heavily on [[multiple-choice]] items, measuring primarily low-level knowledge and some basic skills.{{cite book|last1=Darling-Hammond|first1=Linda|last2=Adamson|first2=Frank|title=Developing Assessments of Deeper Learning: The Costs and Benefits of Using Tests that Help Students Learn|date=2013|publisher=Stanford Center for Opportunity Policy in Education|location=Stanford, CA|page=i|url=https://edpolicy.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/publications/developing-assessments-deeper-learning-costs-and-benefits-using-tests-help-students-learn_1.pdf}} A study by the [[RAND Corporation]] found that, in the 17 states studied, fewer than 2% of [[mathematics]] items and only about 20% of [[English language|English language arts]] (ELA) items on state tests ask students to analyze, synthesize, compare, critique, investigate, prove, or explain their ideas. However, two federally funded multi-state assessment consortia—the [[Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers]] (PARCC) and the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium (SBAC){{cite web |url=http://www.smarterbalanced.org |title=About |publisher=Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium (SBAC) |accessdate=28 September 2014}} —were formed to develop next-generation assessment tools, to be launched in 2014–15. Research conducted by UCLA's [[National Center for Research on Evaluation, Standards, and Student Testing (CRESST)|CRESST]] show marked increases in the amount of higher-order skills to be assessed as measured by the Depth of Knowledge scale.{{cite web |url=http://www.ode.state.or.us/teachlearn/subjects/socialscience/standards/depthofknowledgechart.pdf |title=Depth of Knowledge scale |publisher= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140612020209/http://www.ode.state.or.us/teachlearn/subjects/socialscience/standards/depthofknowledgechart.pdf |archivedate=12 June 2014}} The Innovation Lab Network (ILN) of states,{{cite web |url=http://www.ccsso.org/What_We_Do/Innovation_Lab_Network.html |title=Innovation Lab Network |publisher=[[Council of Chief State School Officers]] |accessdate=28 September 2014}} coordinated by the [[Council of Chief State School Officers]], convenes a smaller, informal consortium of ten states to develop strategies to create and deploy even more intellectually ambitious assessments. The performance assessments under development by participating states includes tasks that require students to analyze, critique, evaluate, and apply knowledge. The new tests also intend to encourage instruction aimed at helping students acquire and use knowledge in more complex ways. In September 2014, a report was released by the [[American Institutes for Research]] on a three-year, quasi-experimental comparison of traditional and Deeper Learning schools. The research findings demonstrated the following improved student outcomes: students attending deeper learning network schools benefited from greater opportunities to engage in deeper learning and reported higher levels of academic engagement, motivation to learn, self-efficacy, and collaboration skills; students had higher state standardized assessment scores regardless of student background; students scored higher on PISA-based Test for Schools{{cite web |url=http://www.oecd.org/pisa/aboutpisa/pisa-basedtestforschools.htm |title=PISA-based Test for Schools |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) |accessdate=2014}} on measures of core content knowledge and complex problem-solving skills; students graduated on time at statistically significantly higher rates (9 percent); and after graduation students were more likely to attend four-year colleges and enroll in more selective institutions.{{cite web |url=http://www.air.org/resource/evidence-deeper-learning-outcomes |title=Evidence of Deeper Learning Outcomes |publisher=American Institutes for Research |date=24 September 2014 |accessdate=28 September 2014}}{{cite journal|last1=Bellanca|first1=James|title=Deepening Critical Thinking|journal=P21 Blogazine|date=June 23, 2014|volume=1|issue=5|page=13}}{{cite journal|last1=Bellanca|first1=James A.|title=Critical Thinking|journal=P21 Blogazine|date=November 2014|volume=1|issue=9|page=10}}{{cite book|last1=Bellanca|first1=James A.|title=Enriched Learning Projects|date=2010|publisher=Solution Tree Press|location=Bloomington, In|isbn=978-1-934009-74-1|pages=223|edition=1st|url=http://www.solution-tree.org}}{{cite book|last1=Bellanca|first1=James A.|title=Deeper Learning: Beyond 21st Century Skills|date=2015|publisher=Solutions Tree Press|location=United States|isbn=978-1-936763-35-1|pages=390|edition=1|url=http://www.solution-tree.org}}{{cite book|last1=Bellanca |last2=Brandt|first1=James A. |first2=Ronald|title=21st Century Skills: Rethinking How Students Learn|date=2010|publisher=Solution Tree Press|location=United {{Expand Japanese|土偶|date=September 2013}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Dogu Miyagi 1000 BCE 400 BCE.jpg|thumb|Dogū, Ebisuda Site in [[Tajiri, Miyagi|Tajiri]], [[Miyagi Prefecture]], 1000–400 BC.]] [[File:Figurine Dogu Jomon Musée Guimet 70608 3.jpg|thumb|Figurine Dogū, Jomon. [[Musée Guimet]] (70608 3).]] [[File:Dogū of Jōmon Venus.JPG|thumb|[[Jōmon Venus]], National Treasure of Japan, Togariishi Jōmon Archeological Museum.]] {{nihongo|'''''Dogū'''''|土偶||meaning "earthen figures"|lead=yes}}{{Needs IPA}} are small humanoid and animal [[figurine]]s made during the late [[Jōmon period]] (14,000–400 BC) of prehistoric [[Japan]].{{Ref|A|A}} Dogū come exclusively from the Jōmon period. By the [[Yayoi period]], which followed the Jōmon period, Dogū were no longer made. There are various styles of Dogū, depending on exhumation area and time period. According to the [[National Museum of Japanese History]], the total number found throughout Japan is approximately 15,000. Dogū were made across all of Japan, except [[Okinawa]].<ref name="d">{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Dijitaru Daijisen |title=土偶 |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-07-20 |year=2012 |publisher=Shogakukan |location=Tokyo |language=Japanese |trans-title=Dogū |oclc=56431036 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref> Most of the Dogū have been found in eastern Japan and it is rare to find one in western Japan. The purpose of the Dogū remains unknown and should not be confused with the clay [[haniwa]] funerary objects of the [[Kofun period]] (250 – 538).<ref name="enc">{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Japan |title=Jōmon figurines |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-07-21 |year=2012 |publisher=Shogakukan |location=Tokyo |oclc=56431036 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref>
Everyday ceramic items from the period are called [[Jōmon pottery]].
==Origins== Some scholars theorize the Dogū acted as [[Effigy|effigies]] of people, that manifested some kind of [[sympathetic magic]].<ref name="kokushi">{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Kokushi Daijiten |title=土偶 |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-07-21 |year=2012 |publisher=Shogakukan |location=Tokyo |language=Japanese |trans-title=Dogū |oclc=683276033 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref> For example, it may have been believed that illnesses could be transferred into the Dogū, then destroyed, clearing the illness, or any other misfortune.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1 =Insolla|first1 =Timothy|title=The new hakodate jomon culture center, minamikayabe, japan|journal =[[Taylor & Francis|Taylor & Francis (journal)]]|doi =10.2752/175183412X13346797480439}}</ref>
==Characteristics== Dogū are made of [[clay]] and are small, typically 10 to 30 cm high.<ref name="enc" /> Most of the figurines appear to be modeled as female, and have big eyes, small waists, and wide hips.<ref name="d" /> They are considered by many to be representative of goddesses. Many have large abdomens associated with pregnancy, suggesting that the Jomon considered them [[mother goddess]]es.<ref name="enc" /> According to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], these figurines "suggest an association with fertility and shamanistic rites".<ref>http://www.metmuseum.org/</ref> The dogū tend to have large faces, small arms and hands and compact bodies. Some appear to wear [[goggle]]s or have "heart-shaped" faces. Most have marks on the face, chest and shoulders, that suggest [[tattoo]]ing and probable incision with [[bamboo]].<ref>Takayama (1970) "Archaeology, Ethnology & Anthropology of Eurasia", p.76-77</ref><ref>Arnold Rubin (1988) "Marks of civilization: artistic transformations of the human body", p.111-113</ref><ref>Margo DeMello(1992) "Encyclopedia of Body Adornment", p.167</ref>
==Dogū types== * "heart shaped (or crescent-shaped eyebrow) type" figurine * "horned-owl type" figurine<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sitereports.nabunken.go.jp/11828|title=上境旭台貝塚３|last=Public interest Ibaraki education foundation Foundation|first=|date=2013|website=Comprehensive Database of Archaeological Site Reports in Japan|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-01}}</ref> * "goggle-eyed type" (Shakōki-dogū) figurine * "pregnant woman type" figurine<ref name="nakajima" />
==Shakōki-dogū== [[Image:JomonStatue.JPG|thumb|200px|''Shakōki-dogū'' ([[:ja:遮光器土偶|遮光器土偶]]) (1000–400 BCE), "goggle-eyed type" figurine. [[Tokyo National Museum]], [[Japan]].]]
The {{nihongo|''Shakōki-dogū''|遮光器土偶}}, or "goggle-eyed dogū," were created in the Jōmon era, and are so well known that when most Japanese hear the term ''dogū'', this is the image that comes to mind. The name "shakōki" (literally "light-blocking device") comes from the resemblance of the figures' eyes to traditional [[Inuit snow goggles]]. Another distinguishing feature of the objects are the exaggerated, feminine buttocks, chest and thighs.<ref name="nakajima">{{cite journal | last1 = Nakajima | first1 = Toshio | year = 1943 | script-title=ja:石器時代土偶の乳房及び下腹部膨隆に就いて |trans-title=On the Breasts and Swollen Hips of Stone Age Dōgu | journal =Jinruigaku Zasshi | volume = 58 | issue = 7 | pages = 294–295 | location = Tōkyō | publisher = Tōkyō Jinrui Gakkai | language = Japanese | format = PDF | accessdate = July 21, 2012 | url = https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/ase1911/58/7/58_7_287/_pdf}}</ref> Furthermore, the abdomen is covered with patterns, many of which seem to have been painted with [[vermilion]]. The larger figures are hollow, presumably in order to prevent cracking during the [[Pottery#Firing|firing]] process.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008 |reason= Who has said this and where?}}
Unbroken figures are rare, and most are missing an arm, leg or other body part. In many cases, the parts have been cut off. One theory is that parts of the figures may have been cut off in fertility rituals{{Citation needed|date=July 2008 |reason= Whose theory is this?}}.
These types of dogū have been found in the Kamegaoka Site in [[Tsugaru, Aomori|Tsugaru]], [[Aomori Prefecture]]; the Teshiromori Site in [[Morioka, Iwate|Morioka]], [[Iwate Prefecture]]; the Ebisuda Site in [[Tajiri, Miyagi|Tajiri]], [[Miyagi Prefecture]]; and the Izumisawa Kaizuka Site in [[Ishinomaki, Miyagi|Ishinomaki]], [[Miyagi Prefecture]]. All the sites listed have been designated as [[Important Cultural Properties of Japan|Important Cultural Properties]].
==Pseudoarchaeology== {{See|Out-of-place artifact}} Due in part to the enigmatic nature of the figurines, there have been numerous theories of non-scientific nature regarding their ornate appearance with some speculating that the physical appearance is connected to the suits and equipment of modern-day astronauts. One proponent in particular, [[Erich von Däniken]], has written how the dogū (referred in the text as the "Japanese statue of Tokomai") "...has modern fastenings and eye apertures on its helmet",<ref>von Däniken, Erich. ''Chariots of the Gods?''. Bantam Books, 1968.</ref> an attribution made as part of the final chapter of his 1968 publication ''[[Chariots of the Gods?]]'' despite lacking any evidence for the claim.
There are also disparities in the varieties of dogū, with only a portion of the figures having the characteristic goggle-like eyes which is most cited by [[ancient alien]] theorists.
==See also== * [[Haniwa]] * [[National Treasures of Japan]] * [[Tokyo National Museum]] * [[Venus figurine]], a type of clay figure found in archeological cultures throughout the world
== Footnotes == :A.{{Note|A}}In the [[Japanese language]] ''dogū'' is a generic term for any humanoid figure made of clay. The clay figures of prehistoric Eastern Europe, such as the [[Pit–Comb Ware culture]], are also referred to as ''dogū'' in Japanese.<ref name="d" /><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Nihon Kokugo Daijiten |title=土偶 |trans-title=Dogū |url=http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |accessdate=2012-07-21 |year=2012 |publisher=Shogakukan |location=Tokyo |language=Japanese |oclc=56431036 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825113418/http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ |archivedate=2007-08-25 |df= }}</ref>
== References == <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.tnm.jp/?lang=en Tokyo National Museum] * [http://www.rekihaku.ac.jp/english/index.html The National Museum of Japanese History] * [http://sitereports.nabunken.go.jp/en Comprehensive Database of Archaeological Site Reports in Japan], Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110927185317/http://www.um.u-tokyo.ac.jp/dm2k-umdb/umdb/DG Dogū from the Jōmon period, a photographic imagery database]—Tokyo University, Japan {{Languageicon|ja}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120722233141/http://metropolis.co.jp/arts/art-reviews/the-power-of-dogu/ Review of recent exhibition of Dogū at the Tokyo National Museum] * [https://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/museum_in_london/london_exhibition_archive/the_power_of_dogu.aspx British Museum exhibition] of Dogū from Japanese museums, 2009

https://letters.foundation/
https://learningbygivingfoundation.org/ }} '''Doris Buffett''' (b. February 12, 1928) is an American philanthropist also known as the 'retail' philanthropist and the founder of ''The Sunshine Lady Foundation'', ''The Learning By Giving Foundation'', and ''The Letters Foundation'' who she co-founded alongside her younger brother, billionaire [[Warren Buffett]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/work-in-progress/2012/05/05/the-buffett-legacy-the-seven-pearls-of-financial-wisdom/#7c99a6c114df|title=The Buffett Legacy: The Seven Pearls of Financial Wisdom|last=Webster|first=Camilla|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118609856620086774|title=The Other Buffett|last=Beatty|first=Sally|date=2007-08-03|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} She is also the daughter of U.S. politician and stockbroker [[Howard Homan Buffett]]. Doris Buffett intends to give all of her money away before she dies.{{Cite news|url=https://www.omaha.com/money/buffett/doris-buffett-has-alzheimer-s-and-now-her-foundation-is/article_fcfd35a8-89e0-527c-a795-063216437a3c.html|title=Doris Buffett has Alzheimer’s, and now her foundation is the basis of a dispute|last=writer|first=Steve Jordon World-Herald staff|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://bangordailynews.com/2010/07/29/uncategorized/philanthropist-doris-buffett-shares-life-anecdotes-at-museum-benefit/|title=Philanthropist Doris Buffett shares life anecdotes at museum benefit|work=Bangor Daily News|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://philanthropynewsdigest.org/news/doris-buffett-is-looking-for-a-few-good-volunteers|title=Doris Buffett Is Looking for a Few Good Volunteers|last=Center|first=Foundation|work=Philanthropy News Digest (PND)|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} == Biography == Doris Buffett is the granddaughter of Ernest Buffett who operated a family grocery store in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. Her father Howard Homan Buffett, founded the Omaha based investment business Buffett-Falk & Company in 1931.{{Cite web|url=https://www.investinganswers.com/education/famous-investors/whats-so-great-about-warren-buffett-anyway-314|title=What's So Great about Warren Buffett, Anyway? {{!}} InvestingAnswers|website=www.investinganswers.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-10}} She is the oldest sister of Warren Buffett, the chief executive of [[Berkshire Hathaway]], and the [[The World's Billionaires|third-wealthiest person in the world]]. Buffett grew up in [[Kansas]], suffered through the [[Great Depression]] and saw frugal times as a young wife before her inheritance that now allows her to do philanthropic work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fredericksburg.com/discover/difference-maker-hall-of-fame-doris-buffett-giving-fortune-away/article_302581bd-6e42-5b54-809b-2729cdc40fe6.html|title=Difference Maker Hall of Fame: Doris Buffett giving fortune away to help improve others' lives|last=Jacobs|first=MICHAEL ZITZ PHOTO BY Erik|work=Fredericksburg.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} She was married four times and has fought two bouts of cancer. Buffett attracted attention with the publication of a 2010 book titled, “''Giving It All Away: The Doris Buffett Story'',” which was authored by Michael Zitz. The book, which she pursued at the urging of her brother Warren Buffett and the lead singer of U2 [[Bono]], describes Doris' background and life as a philanthropist.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wilmingtonbiz.com/nonprofit/2010/08/05/doris_buffett_gives_it_all_away/1706 Buffett has donated $100 million of her own money, mostly to needy individuals, often taking the time to call and write to them personally and determine the best way to help. Through her ''Sunshine Lady Foundation'' she has helped thousands of children get an education or attend camp, sponsored young women in Afghanistan and supports prison education programs amongst other philanthropy work. Her goal is to give away her entire fortune, which remains substantial despite her generosity and the stock market crash of 2008.{{Cite news|url=https://www.richmond.com/news/virginia/fredericksburg-renames-public-pool-in-honor-of-philanthropist-doris-buffett/article_77334d0c-0dfa-53ca-8513-e2ae71d56992.html|title=Fredericksburg renames public pool in honor of philanthropist Doris Buffett, sister of Warren Buffett|last=LANCE-STAR|first=CATHY JETT THE FREE|work=Richmond Times-Dispatch|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} She established the ''Letters Foundation'' alongside her brother Warren Buffett to provide humanitarian grants to people experiencing a crisis through no fault of their own, when no other options exist. A hand-up and not hand-out is her philanthropy principle. Her brother Warren Buffett helped fund some of the foundation’s early projects though later she began providing funds herself from Berkshire Hathway stocks she owned. Unlike brother Warren Buffett who grants in 'wholesale', Doris Buffett believes in small and direct grants to people with financial difficulties hence the nickname 'retail' philanthropist.{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.de/Giving-All-Away-Doris-Buffett/dp/1579622097|title=Giving It All Away the Doris Buffett Sto: The Doris Buffett Story|last=Suchergebnisse|date=2010-05-01|publisher=Permanent Pr Pub Co|isbn=9781579622091|location=Sag Harbor, NY|language=Englisch}} "She is far more philanthropic than I am. She identifies with the underdog. I do it in a wholesale way, but not on a one-on-one basis. She really wants to know their stories," Warren Buffett said to the Wall Street Journal. Doris Buffett also established the ''Learning By Giving Foundation'' which promotes the study of experiential philanthropy at various undergraduate colleges across the United States. At the end of the semester, each class receives a grant of $10,000 to distribute to local nonprofit organizations. The courses help students understand the social and economic roles of the nonprofit sector and philanthropy, and the processes through which social change is funded and implemented across sectors. Buffett made her home in [[Fredericksburg, Virginia]] and moved to [[Boston]] in 2016 to be closer to family, and to receive treatment for [[Alzheimer’s disease]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.fredericksburg.com/opinion/editorials/editorial-buffett-s-philanthropy-has-left-its-mark/article_bb190119-b203-5e00-85f7-c151fa2f531d.html|title=EDITORIAL: Buffett's philanthropy has left its mark|last=LANCE-STAR|first=THE EDITORIAL PAGE STAFF OF THE FREE|work=Fredericksburg.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessbreakingnews.net/2018/05/doris-buffett-has-alzheimers-and-now-her-foundation-is-the-basis-of-a-dispute/|title=Doris Buffett has Alzheimer’s, and now her foundation is the basis of a dispute|date=2018-05-13|work=Business Breaking News|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}} == See also == * [[Warren Buffett]] * [[Howard Buffett]] * [[Peter Buffett]] * [[Susan Alice Buffett]] == References == == External links == [https://www.sunshinelady.org/ Official website] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=94&v=kHU-YrZgARs Buffett interview] {{Buffett Family}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:20th-century American women]] [[Category:Buffett family]] [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Philanthropists]] [[Category:Philanthropy in the United States]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
'''Line 3''' is an [[oil sands]] [[Petroleum|crude oil]] [[Pipeline transport|pipeline]] that runs from [[Hardisty|Hardisty, Alberta]] to [[Superior, Wisconsin]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.enbridge.com/~/media/Enb/Documents/Projects/Line%203/ProjectHandouts/ENB_Line3_Public_Affairs_ProjectSummary.pdf|title=Line 3 Replacement Project Summary|last=|first=|date=|website=Enbridge|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Construction of a new route for Line 3 has been proposed by the Canadian oil company, [[Enbridge]].<ref name=":0" /> While this project was easily approved in [[Canada]],<ref name=":19" /> [[Wisconsin]],<ref name=":20" /> and [[Canada|North Dakota]],<ref name=":21" /> the proposed pipeline has received resistance from [[Environmentalism|environmental]] groups and [[Native Americans in the United States|U.S. Native American]] communities in Minnesota.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/06/29/line-3-opponents-gird-for-fight-over-approved-pipeline|title=Line 3 opponents girding for fight over approved pipeline|last=Kraker|first=Dan|date=June 29, 2018|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== History of Line 3 and the New Proposed Route ==
Construction on the original Line 3 pipeline started in 1962.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/04/23/timeline-line-3-enbridge-oil-pipeline|title=Line 3 timeline: From construction to present day battles|last=Nelson|first=Cody|date=April 23, 2018|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It began operating in 1968 to meet growing U.S. demand for oil.<ref name=":2" /> Since its construction, the pipeline has carried on average between 390,000 and 760,000 [[Barrel (unit)|barrels]] of oil per day.<ref name=":0" /> Numerous structural anomalies have developed along the pipeline over time.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/commerce/energyfacilities/resource.html?Id=34735|title=Line 3 EIS: Executive Summary|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Department of Commerce|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> These holes, and concerns about the safety of the pipeline, have led Enbridge to reduce the amount of oil transported daily.<ref name=":0" /> Enbridge announced plans to build the new Line 3 in 2014.<ref name=":2" /> That multi-billion dollar project would allow Enbridge to restore their historic operating capacity and move nearly 800,000 barrels per day.<ref name=":0" />
While governing bodies in Canada,<ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/enbridge-neb-line3-replacement-oilpatch-1.3551964|title=NEB approves Enbridge Line 3 pipeline replacement|last=Bakx|first=Kyle|date=April 25, 2016|website=CBC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> North Dakota,<ref name=":21">{{Cite web|url=http://www.grandforksherald.com/news/4112645-sandpiper-deferred-enbridge-moving-forward-line-3-replacement|title=Sandpiper deferred, but Enbridge is moving forward with Line 3 replacement|last=Liedke|first=Mattew|date=September 10, 2016|website=Grand Forks Herald|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and Wisconsin<ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=https://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/environment/wisconsin-dnr-approves-enbridge-oil-line/article_abf7118c-cf96-5866-8339-2e429bc9f8a9.html|title=Wisconsin DNR approves 1 Enbridge oil line|last=Verburg|first=Steven|date=August 30, 2016|website=Wisconsin State Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> had approved their segments of the pipeline by 2016, approval took longer in Minnesota where environmentalists have resisted the project.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/06/25/mn-regulators-decide-this-week-enbridge-line3|title=Minnesota regulators to decide this week on Enbridge Line 3|last=|first=|date=June 25, 2018|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In advance of their decision on Line 3 the MN Public Utilities Commission (PUC) solicited public input about Line 3.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/puc/assets/2018_04_23_Line_3_ALJ_Report_tcm14-336840.pdf?sourcePage=%2fpuc%2fline3%2fdocuments%2findex.jsp%3fnull|title=STATE OF MINNESOTA, OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS, FOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION; In the Matter of the Application of Enbridge Energy, Limited Partnership, for a Certificate of Need for the Line 3 Project in Minnesota from the North Dakota Border to the Wisconsin Border; In the Matter of the Application of Applicant Enbridge Energy, Limited Partnership for a Routing Permit for the Line 3 Project in Minnesota from the North Dakota Border to the Wisconsin Border; FINDINGS OF FACT, CONCLUSIONS OF LAW, AND RECOMMENDATION|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Public Utilities Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Most feedback they received opposed the pipeline.<ref name=":4" /> Of the nearly 70,000 individual comments that were submitted, 68,244, or 94%, voiced opposition to the pipeline's completion.<ref name=":4" /> However, in June 2018 the PUC granted Enbridge the Certificate of Need and approved their desired route for Line 3.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kstp.com/news/enbridge-line-three-state-regulators-public-utilities-commission-vote/4968065/|title=State Regulators Approve Enbridge Pipeline Proposal Certificate of Need|last=|first=|date=June 28, 2018|website=5 ABC: Eyewitness News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Environmentalists and Native communities in the state have pledged to resist the pipeline's construction.<ref name=":22" />
== Line 3 Controversy in Minnesota == Much of the resistance to the Line 3 project comes from concerns over climate change. Environmental groups such as the North Star Chapter of the [[Sierra Club]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sierraclub.org/sites/www.sierraclub.org/files/sce/north-star-chapter/pdf/Line3FactSheet.pdf|title=Line 3 and the Pipeline System|last=|first=|date=|website=Sierra Club North Star Chapter|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> MN350,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mn350.org/pipeline-resistance/|title=Pipeline Resistance|last=|first=|date=|website=MN350|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Honor the Earth]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.honorearth.org/sandpiper_line_3_corridor|title=Line 3|last=|first=|date=|website=Honor the Earth|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> have anti-Line 3 campaigns. The [[Environmental impact statement|Environmental Impact Statement]] (EIS), which was conducted by the [[Minnesota Department of Commerce]], explains how the new Line 3 pipeline would contribute to deforestation, increase risk of pollution to Minnesota's pristine water ecosystems and [[wild rice]] beds, and generate greenhouse gasses that contribute to climate change.<ref name=":3" /> Since the publication of the EIS, the MN Department of Commerce has formally denounced the proposed Line 3 project on environmental grounds, going so far as to say that they would prefer to see the old pipeline cease operations:<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/4326044-enbridge-line-3-replacement-not-needed-minn-commerce-department-says|title=Enbridge Line 3 replacement not needed, Minn. commerce department says|last=Johnson|first=Brooks|date=September 11, 2017|website=Bemidji Pioneer|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[File:EPA's response to the Enbridge oil spill (4854647663).jpg|alt=The EPA tries to clean oil out of the front yards of residents near the spill|thumb|280x280px|[[Kalamazoo River oil spill|2010 Enbridge Oil Spill]]]]
{{quote|In light of the serious risks and effects on the natural and socioeconomic environments of the existing Line 3 and the limited benefit that the existing Line 3 provides to Minnesota refineries, it is reasonable to conclude that Minnesota would be better off if Enbridge proposed to cease operations of the existing Line 3, without any new pipeline being built.|Minnesota Department of Commerce <ref name=":5" />}}
One specific concern about the project is the potential for [[oil spill]]s along Line 3.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/03/27/line-3-enbridge-minnesota-spill-fears-versus-safety|title=Spill fears rise even as Line 3 backers vow new pipeline will be safe|last=Kraker|first=Dan|date=May 27, 2019|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In recent years, Enbridge has safely transported 99.999% of oil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/06/20/rivers-of-oil-podcast-line3-pipeline-ep2-spill|title=Rivers of Oil, Episode 2: The largest inland spill|last=Kraker|first=Dan|date=June 20, 2018|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, among other accidental releases, the original Line 3 pipeline was responsible for the largest ever inland oil spill in the U.S.<ref name=":2" /> In 1991, 1.7 million gallons of oil ruptured from Line 3 in [[Grand Rapids, Minnesota|Grand Rapids, MN]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/2d06afe9e6c0712a86b91309d7c4932b|title=Company Revises Minnesota Oil Spill Upward to 1.7 Million Gallons|last=|first=|date=March 13, 1991|website=AP News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Enbridge was also responsible for the [[Kalamazoo River oil spill|2010 spill]] on the [[Kalamazoo River|Kalamazoo river]] in Michigan.<ref name=":2" /> After 8 years and over a billion dollars spent, that spill is still being cleaned up.<ref name=":2" /> The resulting pollution has adversely affected the economy,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fox17online.com/2016/07/20/2010-enbridge-oil-spill-in-kalamazoo-river-a-lasting-effect-on-local-business/|title=2010 Enbridge oil spill in Kalamazoo River: a lasting effect on local business|last=Chicklas|first=Dana|date=July 20, 2016|website=FOX 17 West Michigan|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> public health,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.michigan.gov/documents/mdch/Enbridge_Sediment__BLUE_FINAL_5-23-2012_387874_7.pdf|title=Public Health Assessment Kalamazoo River/Enbridge Spill|last=|first=|date=May 23, 2012|website=Michigan Department of Community Health|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and the environment<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fws.gov/midwest/news/785.html|title=For Immediate Release: Enbridge Must Restore Environment Injured by 2010 Kalamazoo River Oil Spill|last=Parham|first=Georgia|date=June 8, 2015|website=U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in MIchigan. Enbridge has consistently reassured the public that pipeline safety is their primary goal.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.enbridge.com/~/media/Enb/Documents/Projects/line5/Our_commitment_to_pipeline_safety.pdf?la=en|title=Our commitment to pipeline safety|last=|first=|date=|website=Enbridge|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> They employ technology to monitor pipelines, and train employees on emergency response.<ref name=":7" /> While significant oil spills (>238 barrels of oil) have decreased in recent years,<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/commerce/energyfacilities/resource.html?Id=34735|title=Line 3 EIS: Chapter 10 - Accidental Crude Oil Releases|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Department of Commerce|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> organizers in Minnesota feel that the potential for even one serious spill is too much of a risk.<ref name=":6" /> The Environmental Impact Statement on Line 3 acknowledges that some accidental release of oil is inevitable and that serious oil spills are possible.<ref name=":8" />
Many Native communities in Minnesota oppose Line 3. Five [[Anishinaabe]] tribes, the [[White Earth Band of Ojibwe|White Earth]], Red Lake, [[Mille Lacs Band of Ojibwe|Mille Lacs]], [[Fond du Lac Band of Lake Superior Chippewa|Fond du Lac]], and [[Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe|Leech Lake]] bands hold status as intervening parties against the project in the PUC's permit deliberations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stopline3.org/news/5tribes|title=5 Ojibwe Tribes Intervene in Minnesota's Contested Case Process for Line 3|last=|first=|date=July 13, 2017|website=Stop Line 3|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that the construction of Line 3 would disrupt tribal cultural sites such as burial grounds and historic locales, and degrade natural resources such as wild rice beds and healthy water ecosystems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/commerce/energyfacilities/resource.html?Id=34735|title=Line 3 EIS: Chapter 9 - Tribal Resources|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Department of Commerce|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A complete Traditional Cultural Properties Survey has not been conducted of the proposed route.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/tribes-ask-puc-to-reconsider-review-of-new-enbridge-pipeline-route-saying-cultural-study-wasn-t-done/468049673/|title=Tribes ask PUC to reconsider review of new Enbridge pipeline route, saying cultural study wasn't done|last=Hughlett|first=Mike|date=January 4, 2018|website=Star Tribune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> One will not take place unless a permit for construction is granted to Enbridge.<ref name=":9" /> This lack has been criticized by tribal groups.<ref name=":9" /> The [[Minnesota Chippewa Tribe]], in conjunction with Honor the Earth, an Indigenous climate justice organization, released their own assessment of the cultural and environmental determinants Line 3 would have on their land.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mnchippewatribe.org/pdf/Intro_DRAFT.pdf|title=Anishinaabe Cumulative Impact Assessment on the Proposed Enbridge Line 3 Expansion and Abandonment Plan|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Chippewa Tribe|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The Chippewa Cumulative Impact Assessment reflects grave concern in that community and strongly opposes the pipeline's construction.<ref name=":10" /> In response to such concerns, Enbridge has an 'Indigenous Peoples Policy' which lays out guidelines for the company's work on Native land.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.enbridge.com/sustainability-reports/indigenous-discussion-paper/indigenous-policy|title=Enbridge's Indigenous Peoples Policy|last=|first=|date=|website=Enbridge|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Another debate surrounding the proposed Line 3 project is what will happen to the infrastructure of the old Line 3. Enbridge has proposed a process they call "deactivation." <ref name=":0" /> Many who oppose the project call it "abandonment."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pipelinecleanupmn.org/resources/line-3-abandonment-factsheet|title=Line 3 Abandonment Factsheet|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesotans for Pipeline Cleanup|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Enbridge explains deactivation of a pipeline as a 5 step process: remove the oil, clean the pipe, disconnect it from facilities, put corrosion controls in place, and then leave the pipe in the ground.<ref name=":0" /> The method that Enbridge would use to prevent corrosion is called c[[Cathodic protection|athodic protection]].<ref name=":0" /> Minnesotans for Pipeline Cleanup, an organization opposed to Line 3, has expressed concerns about the efficacy of that process.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pipelinecleanupmn.org/sites/default/files/2018-06/Pipeline%20Abandonment%20Report.pdf|title=Enbridge's Mess An Historic Moment for Minnesota Landowners|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesotans for Pipeline Cleanup|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Many landowners along the old route worry that they will bear the financial burden for the decommissioned pipe, either through costs of cleanup, removal, or lost property value.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mnchippewatribe.org/pdf/Chapter%204_Overview%20of%20projects_DRAFT.pdf|title=Chippewa Cumulative Impact Assessment: Chapter 4|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Chippewa Tribe|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Both the Pipeline Abandonment Report from Minnesotans for Pipeline Cleanup and the Chippewa Cumulative Impact Statement mention that Line 3 would be the first pipeline ever to be decommissioned in MN, and try to interrogate what sort of precedent that might set.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12" />
Many Minnesotans support the Line 3 project for its potential to support the economy of communities along the route. Enbridge has said that thousands of jobs will be created as a result of the pipeline's construction.<ref name=":0" /> However, the Environmental Impact Statement draws a distinction between the temporary employment that would be available during construction and the likelihood of long term job creation:<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/commerce/energyfacilities/resource.html?Id=34735|title=Line 3 EIS: Chapter 5 - Existing Conditions, Impacts, and Mitigation - Certificate of Need|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Department of Commerce|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
{{quote|Based on the small number of permanent jobs, it is likely that operation of the pipeline would result in no to negligible impact on the per capita household income, median household income, or unemployment rates in the ROI (region of interest.)|Line 3 Environmental Impact Statement (Chapter 5, page 578) <ref name=":17" />}}
In addition to job creation, Line 3 supporters also cite the positive impact that Enbridge property taxes could have on communities in Northern Minnesota.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://minnesotansforline3.com/about-us/|title=The Line 3 Replacement Project: Safety, Efficiency, Jobs|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesotans for Line 3|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In the first year of the new Line 3's operations, Enbridge would pay $19.5 million in property taxes along the route.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=http://www.enbridge.com/projects-and-infrastructure/public-awareness/minnesota-projects/line-3-replacement-project|title=Line 3 Replacement Project|last=|first=|date=|website=Enbridge|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> That number would increase over time.<ref name=":18" /> Organizers hold some reservations about how impactful that revenue might be,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.honorearth.org/understanding_the_minnesota_doc_s_opposition_testimony_for_line_3|title=Understanding the Minnesota DOC's Opposition Testimony for Line 3|last=|first=|date=|website=Honor the Earth|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> citing Enbridge's recent lawsuit in which their claim that they had been overtaxed indebted counties across Minnesota to Enbridge for tens of millions of dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/enbridge-prevails-in-minnesota-property-tax-challenge/482687251/|title=Enbridge prevails in Minnesota property tax challenge|last=Hughlett|first=Mike|date=May 15, 2018|website=Star Tribune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Another argument in support of the pipeline ties safety to the economic concept of supply and demand. Recent studies have highlighted that train and truck transportation of oil results in more regular spills than transport by pipe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/28/pipelines-vs-trains-oil-transport/|title=Pipelines: The Worst Way to Move Oil, Except For All the Rest|last=Morris|first=David|date=August 28, 2016|website=Fortune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> Among their arguments in support of the pipeline, Minnesotans for Line 3 cites the growing number of trains transporting oil through the state.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://minnesotansforline3.com/2018/05/fact-check-friday-8-supply-demand-and-why-pipelines-like-line-3-are-so-important/|title=Fact Check Friday #8: Supply, demand and why pipelines like Line 3 are so important|last=|first=|date=May 11, 2018|website=Minnesotans for Line 3|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> They argue that, due to high U.S. demand, oil will be moved through the states by whatever means are available.<ref name=":13" /> [[Justin Trudeau]], Prime Minister of Canada, also advanced this argument in his public endorsement of the Canadian section of Line 3:<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/federal-cabinet-trudeau-pipeline-decisions-1.3872828|title=Trudeau cabinet approves Trans Mountain, Line 3 pipelines, rejects Northern Gateway|last=Tasker|first=John|date=November 29, 2016|website=CBC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
{{quote|(Transport of oil by rail) is less economic, and more dangerous for communities, and is higher in terms of greenhouse gas emissions than modern pipelines would be.|Justin Trudeau, Canadian Prime Minister <ref name=":14" />}}
Enbridge estimates that Line 3 would replace more than 10,000 rail cars or 24,000 [[Tank truck|tanker trucks]] transporting oil everyday.<ref name=":0" /> Minnesotans for Line 3 say that by approving the pipeline, government regulators could ensure safer transport of millions of barrels of oil a year.<ref name=":13" /> The MN Department of Commerce, in their testimony against Line 3, questioned these projections, claiming that they depend on an unrealistic idea of the future demand of oil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mn.gov/eera/web/project-file?legacyPath=/opt/documents/34079/Fagan_Direct_Testimony%2014-916.pdf|title=BEFORE THE MINNESOTA OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS; FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION; IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF ENBRIDGE ENERGY, LIMITED PARTNERSHIP FOR A CERTIFICATE OF NEED FOR THE LINE 3 REPLACEMENT PROJECT IN MINNESOTA FROM THE NORTH DAKOTA BORDER TO THE WISCONSIN BORDER; DIRECT TESTIMONY OF DR. MARIE FAGAN ON BEHALF OF MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE DIVISION OF ENERGY RESOURCES|last=|first=|date=|website=Minnesota Department of Commerce|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Enbridge's key argument in support of the pipeline relates to that critique from the Department of Commerce. Today, U.S. Americans consume more petroleum than any other source of energy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=10|title=History of energy consumption in the United States|last=|first=|date=|website=U.S. Energy Information Administration|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Oil and its byproducts fuel cars, pave roads, and even make up the foundation for many cosmetic products and synthetic fabrics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://listverse.com/2012/12/23/10-everyday-things-that-started-life-as-oil/|title=10 Everyday Things That Started Life As Oil|last=Sullivan|first=Jason|date=December 23, 2012|website=Listverse|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Enbridge calls Line 3 a "vital link," supplying that highly demanded oil to Minnesota and the United States.<ref name=":0" /> While many analysts in the industry believe that demand for oil will eventually begin to fall, no one can predict when that will be.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/get-ready-for-peak-oil-demand-1495419061|title=Get Ready for Peak Oil Demand|last=Cook|first=Lynn|last2=Cherney|first2=Elena|date=May 26, 2017|website=Wall Street Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Some environmentalists worry about future decreased demand, concerned with the notion of [[stranded asset]]s.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/fossil-fuel-investment-capital-stranded-1.3524952|title=Warning for investors, not just environmentalists, in fossil fuel spending: Don Pittis|last=Pittis|first=Don|date=April 8, 2016|website=CBC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A stranded asset is equipment or a product that can't be turned into profit because of some change in the demand.<ref name=":15" /> Environmentalists raise the question of what will happen to oil infrastructure when the companies that owned them are no longer profitable or cease to operate.<ref name=":15" />
With environmentalists vowing to fight the pipeline,<ref name=":22" /> government officials are concerned about what sort of resistance might materialize as construction begins.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/05/03/minnesota-county-officials-worry-about-potential-pipeline-protest-cost|title=Minnesota county officials worry about potential pipeline protest cost|last=|first=|date=May 3, 2018|website=MPRNews|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Commentators have compared the potential resistance to the front line protests over the [[Keystone Pipeline#Keystone XL|Keystone XL]] and [[Dakota Access Pipeline|Dakota Access]] Pipelines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanexperiment.org/2018/06/will-line-3-become-next-major-pipeline-protest/|title=Will Line 3 Become the Next Major Pipeline Protest?|last=Orr|first=Isaac|date=June 18, 2018|website=Center of the American Experiment|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Environmentalists have already pursued legal intervention,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://energynews.us/2017/10/23/midwest/landmark-decision-casts-youth-as-official-intervenors-in-pipeline-case/|title='Landmark' decision casts youth as official intervenors in pipeline case|last=Jossi|first=Frank|date=October 23, 2017|website=Energy News Network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> direct action,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kbjr6.com/story/36247257/sheriffs-office-says-six-arrested-enbridge-says-they-were-unlawful-honor-the-earth-says-it-was-peacefulnon-violent|title=Six arrested: Enbridge says they were unlawful, Honor the Earth says it was peaceful|last=Marozas|first=Ramona|date=August 29, 2017|website=KBJR6|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/crime-and-courts/4387157-three-arrested-protest-wells-fargo-bank-downtown-duluth|title=Three arrested in protest at Wells Fargo bank in downtown Duluth|last=Slater|first=Brady|date=January 12, 2018|website=Duluth News Tribune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and more creative resistance<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.citypages.com/arts/activists-protest-the-line-3-oil-pipeline-this-weekend-in-st-paul-with-art-and-music/482835771|title=Activists protest the Line 3 oil pipeline this weekend in St. Paul with art and music|last=Regan|first=Sheila|date=May 17, 2018|website=City Pages|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> to the pipeline, so officials along the route fear that the next phase of resistance to Line 3 could incur high security costs and disruption to life along the proposed route.<ref name=":16" />
